results.description:
La Plaza Permaculture Workshop Series
http://laplazacultural.com/#4

Introduction to Urban Permaculture with Andrew Faust
Saturday, Nov. 7th 10am-2pm at La Plaza Cultural Garden

Learn to apply Permaculture Design to retrofit NYC to be a healthier and happier place for people to live in. Learn how to use principles of permaculture in the urban landscape and ways to create deeply ecological businesses and enterprises like improving rooftop farms, restaurant farm to table operations, bicycle compost pick up, rooftop edible native plant landscaping, natural non-toxic interior design, and cleaning indoor air with houseplants.
Also covered in this workshop will be learning to design permaculture landscapes, site analysis/design techniques for rooftop farms, city gardens and business models, working with bees, raising chickens and other micro-livestock in urban settings.
Design your life and your livelihood to be a part of creating a better and healthier world for all.

Free to Garden Members!
(suggested donation $10-$20) Hot Apple Cider

We will also take a quick tour of La Plaza's permaculture features including a great compost system, hugelbeds, member supported CSA beds, a bioswale, chickens, espalier fruit tress, water catch systems, our nature trail and the Shad fruit and nut orchard.

About Andrew:
Andrew Faust is one of North America's premier permaculture teachers and designers with nearly two decades of experience in the field. His passionate and visionary presentation and curriculum has been inspiring and motivating students since his days as an alternative school teacher at Upattinas in Glenmoore, PA.
Andrew lived off the grid in West Virginia for 8 years where he designed and built a Permaculture inspired homestead including a 1600 sq ft strawbale house. He moved to Brooklyn in 2007 and has been applying his knowledge to the urban landscape culminating in a Permaculture Design Certification course many consider life changing. He is developing The Center for Bioregional Living in Ellenville, NY with his partner Adriana Magana as a pilot campus for his students, clients and baby daughter Juniper.

The Center for Bioregional Living
Ellenville/ Brooklyn, NY
www.permaculturenewyork.com

Bring your own ipod & earbuds. We dance walk around the park loop--everybody listens to their own music. What is dance walking? It's an improvised form of walking, with music, doing whatever movement comes naturally. It's walking and moving your arms. Or skipping, skitching, low-stepping, sideways running. It's responding to the rhythm, attitude, or story of the music you're hearing. In short, it's having a dance party in your living room, while walking through the park--hilarious and exhilarating. results.description:
Unusual Tour in one of the most famous hotels in the world Waldorf-Astoria Hotel which includes lunch in a famous Peacock Alley restaurant inside of the hotel. 

The tour will include a professional Waldorf Astoria tour guide who will tell us history of the hotel and its memorial stories, will show photographs, and will take us to the ball rooms, service rooms, and restaurant and so on. Tour also includes the access to the lunch buffet in the Peacock Alley Restaurant after the actual tour where you can sit and enjoy the interior.

The length of the tour: 1 hour and 15 minutes

Price: $70. Money will be collected in front.

Start: 10:15 am, Saturday

The Waldorf Astoria is one of the kind hotels. All American presidents stopped there while visiting New York City for pleasure or for business.

There is a short video of the hotel:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EJKsL2l8U3w

Waldoft-Astoria Hotel is unique Art Deco structure. Standing in the center of the new York City but it`s neighborhood is pretty quiet and not crowded. Here, every room is has unique interior.  Waldorf –Astoria was the first hotel that offered room service and kids menu. These two options changed the hotel industry forever. Surprisingly, there is a hidden train stop underneath the Waldoft-Astoria. President Franklin Roosevelt used it for visits from Washington DC to New York City. Also there is an elevator constructed specially for Roosevelt`s bulletproof car, connecting the train and the garage. This space was used only once since then. Andy Warhol made his own video art exhibition in 1965.

Presidential rooms have unique amenities like multiple adjacent rooms for staff, bulletproof glass windows, and an interior design similar to the White House make this grand accommodation high up on the 35th floor the number one choice of sitting presidents when they visit New York. Every president since Herbert Hoover has stayed here, including President Obama, who sleeps here every time he’s in town. Each president has also left the hotel a gift that is now featured in the suite (JFK left a rocking chair), so check back in a couple years to see what Obama leaves. Recently the hotel was bought by Chinese company. Fearing of espionage, current president, Barack Obama, did not stop in Waldorf Astoria this year, visiting New York City.

There were filmed such movies as Weekend at the Waldorf , Scent of a Woman, Coming to America.

There are several residential units in the hotel, located on the 28th to 42nd floors known as the Waldorf Towers. These are some of New York’s most desired homes, the smallest coming it at 1,600 square feet and many with a private terrace. All include 24-hour maid service, a private entrance and sky high price tags—some of these rent for upwards of $100,000 per month.

Many famous entertainers played here, including Glenn Miller, Duke Ellington and Count Basie, as the city’s elite dined on gourmet food and hit the dance floor for a spin. For 16 years the house band was led by Rumba King Xavier Cugat, a popular Latin music conductor who earned his chops in Cuba. There was even a terrace for summer dining with a city view. The retractable roof is long gone, but the Starlight Room is still available to host special events. Just this year, there was a gala honoring the memory of British singer Amy Winehouse with entertainment by Tony Bennett, Harry Belafonte and Jennifer Hudson.

results.description:
Note this is section 2 for new members of our group.  There is another announcement for all other members for the same event.

One Tour,  Three Treasures!!!   (Note - a good 6 miles of walking). We'll experience the lovely Brooklyn Botanical Gardens, Prospect Park and Flatbush Brooklyn!  We'll take advantage of the free Saturday morning admission and with any luck there's still be some fall color.

In collaboration with The Noguchi Museum, Brooklyn Botanic Garden is pleased to present a Garden-wide installation of sculptures by the renowned Japanese-American artist Isamu Noguchi. Curated by the Museum's senior curator, Dakin Hart, the show features 18 works from the Museum's permanent collection that have been specifically chosen for various settings at BBG. The centerpiece of the installation is a selection of eight works in the Japanese Hill-and-Pond Garden that interact subtly with the setting’s rolling hills, rocks, pond, and plantings.

“Each sculpture in the installation is meant to appear to have materialized through some extraordinary natural process, but it has actually been sited to connect with the Garden’s rich traditions of scientific inquiry and aesthetic display.” —Dakin Hart, Senior Curator, The Noguchi Museum

There are restrooms in the gardens.  After a stroll through a fascinating section of Prospect Park, we'll take a lunch break (nice cafe in the park - or bring your own).  Nice menu: http://lakesidebrooklyn.com/bluestone/

After lunch we'll visit  downtown Flatbush and see where Barbara Streisand, Neil Diamond and other famous Brooklynites attended High School. Victorian Flatbush, truly one of New York's hidden gems, which began as a Dutch farming village in 1652 and began to develop as a residential suburb in the late 1800's.  Today this group of neighborhoods makes up one of the largest collection of Victorian-era wood frame architecture in the U.S.  Many of the homes contains distinctive ornamental features and thrive on lovely-tree-lined streets.  You won't believe you are in the middle of Brooklyn!

We will end on walk in the Ditmas Park neighborhood, near the Q train at Cortelyou Road for a reasonably quick ride back to Manhattan or Atlantic Avenue for other train connections.  Usual optional hang out for a drink.
results.how_to_find_us: #2/3 subway to Eastern Parkway-Brooklyn Museum station.  We'll meet outside the main entrance.
results.name: FOR NEW GROUP MEMBERS! Brooklyn Botanical Gardens, Prospect Park & Flatbush

results.description: The autumn foliage should finally be at its peak in Central Park, and we'll do a leisurely walk to view some of the changing colors of the large variety of trees to be found there. Meet 10:30 at the Dana Discovery Center (restrooms). You get there by taking the No. 2 or 3 subway to 110th St. & Lenox Ave., exiting at the south end of the station. Or you can take the No. 4 Madison Avenue bus, which also goes to the same location. After entering the park, walk directly east along the Harlem Meer for a short distance to the Discovery Center. Our walk will take us through the North Woods (a forested area which few visitors to the park ever see). Then up the Great Hill (not as high as the name makes it sound!) and down through the Loch and the Ravine. We'll have lunch in the Conservatory Garden, where the chrysanthemums are now in full bloom (bring lunch and beverage). Around a mile altogether at a very leisurely pace. Call or email to let me know you are coming, and if you have any questions. No need to let me know if you are not coming (though I will certainly miss you!). Bob Susser,[masked]; [masked].

results.description:
------------------------------------------------------------
Intro
------------------------------------------------------------

Hey folks! This is a shorter, easier version of the skate I led last year. Last year, we did about 17 miles with lots of hill climb. This year, we're going to do 12.5 miles with an optional bonus 1.5, totalling 14. And we're riding an elevator to eliminate much of the hill climb.

The general plan:

* Meet at the waterfront
* Get a quick tour of Downtown Jersey City
* Ride an elevator
* See breathtaking views from the Heights and Weehawken
* Ride down a big, moderate hill
* Cruise home on the waterfront
* Eat tacos in the open air

Optional segment, for advanced skaters / thrill seekers:

* Ride a different elevator
* Ride down a big, terrifying hill

It's going to be a blast! I can't wait to see you there.

------------------------------------------------------------
What to Expect
------------------------------------------------------------

Sights? Stunning Manhattan skyline views from The Heights, a whirlwind tour of Jersey City (the good, the bad, the ugly), and a nice cruise along the Hoboken waterfront.

How long? 12.5 mile loop with 1.5 optional loop for Hill-of-Death

Pace? Approx 2.5 hours. Meeting point? Paulus Hook Ferry Terminal

Time?
Meeting time: 10:30AM
Skates on at: 10:45AM
Briefing at: 10:55AM
Rolling at: 11AM Lunch at: Approx 1:30PM

Food? Some of the best fresh-mex tacos around. Hills? There's one big hill climb and one big, safe, gradual downhill.

Difficulty? This is a high-intermediate skate. A hair tougher than the average WNS, but way easier than a TNS. You MUST be able to confidently skate steep downhills and uphills, in a group, with traffic, and mount/dismount curbs as necessary. In some neighborhoods, locals may give us the stink eye. You must not break stride as you smile and/or give the stink eye in return.

Road conditions? Moderate. I'll scout the route for rough pavement and make adjustments. We may be able to keep it smooth most of the way.

Rests / water breaks? There are several short rests along the route. Water breaks: I've planned to stop at mile 6 and mile 12 to buy water. We can add another water stop if necessary. There's a bathroom at mile 14.

Bail-out? The route has two bail-out opportunities:

Mile 3: 2nd St Light Rail Station, Hoboken
Mile 10: Hoboken PATH Train

We'll be skating right by these locations, so it's NO problem if we need to let you off and meet you at the restaurant! Can't wait to see you there!

Teaser video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LC3faUkMJXo

Last year's event:

https://www.facebook.com/events/267125096822298/

Rain date: 11/8/2015

------------------------------------------------------------
What to Bring
------------------------------------------------------------
Required:

* Positive attitude
* Skates
* Protective gear
* Wallet
* Water
* Footwear -> if you are taking the ferry/PATH, bring shoes/sandals or else risk being barred entry. I have never had trouble boarding barefoot or in stocking-feet, but I recommend bringing proper footwear just in case.

------------------------------------------------------------
How to Get There
------------------------------------------------------------

--------------------
By Ferry (best route):
--------------------

Take the NY Waterway ferry from World Financial Center to Paulus Hook.
Departs every 15 minutes from 9AM to 9:45PM.

Fare is $2.50 each way, plus the fresh air on the roof deck is really nice.

--------------------
By PATH:
--------------------

Take the Hoboken/Journal Sqaure PATH train to Exchange Place PATH station, then come 2-3 blocks south to the ferry terminal.

Fare is $2.50 each way. You can use a stored-value Metrocard but NOT an unlimited Metrocard.

--------------------
By Car
--------------------
Parking on Sundays is widely available, especially since we are meeting in the business district. Look for spots along Christopher Columbus Ave, Montgomery, Grand, and side streets. There are also several paid lots in the area.


------------------------------------------------------------
Restaurant Info
------------------------------------------------------------

Taqueria Downtown

236 Grove St
Jersey City, NJ 07302

(201)[masked]

https://plus.google.com/105962525654622622938/about

------------------------------------------------------------
Disclaimer
------------------------------------------------------------
You are skating at your own risk. Skating in city streets is an inherently dangerous activity. I do not take any responsibility for your safety. Operate within your limits. I strongly suggest you wear protective gear.

------------------------------------------------------------
Wrap
------------------------------------------------------------

Got questions? I'm an open book. Hit me!

Much love to you all. Hope to see you there!

-David

---
David Y. Kay

results.description: Barry will introduce the Rindler space - the foundation for analyzing acceleration in relativity. Barry and/or Jeff will use this basis to explain the Unruh effect: an observer accelerating in the vacuum sees heat (i.e. radiation) while an observer at rest in the same vacuum sees just plain vacuum. We will then discuss the relation of the Unruh effect to the corresponding duality of Hawking radiation: an observer outside and stationary with respect to a black hole sees heat radiating from that BH, while an observer simply falling through a BH horizon sees nothing unusual. We may explore the possibility that any such relationship could clarify some issues with AMPS black hole rings of fire. Caution: those topics may be entangled ;-)
results.how_to_find_us: near 29th street. The ThoughtWorks conference room is as you enter.
results.name: Rindler space, Unruh effect and Hawking radiation

results.description:
Join the Morris Ski Club on an easy bike ride along the New Jersey side of the Hudson River.  We will meet at the Sheraton in Lincoln Harbor and bike south along the Hudson Waterfront trail. We will bike through Hoboken, Newport section of Jersey City before reaching Liberty State Park.  We will bike around Liberty State Park taking time to see the various sights, memorials and monuments.  We will then bike back to Lincoln Harbor.  We will pick a spot for a late lunch and some drinks.

Important Notes for the bike ride:

1.  This is an easy ride.  The terrain is flat and for the most part we will be on the paved bike pathway although we will have a few spots where we will be on the road for short distances.

2.  The ride is suitable for road, hybrid or mountain bikes although hybrids would probably be a better choice than a road bike. 

3.  Make sure your bike is in working order and have an extra tube.

4.  Bring water and a snack although there will be many places to buy supplies if needed.

5.  Since we will be stopping and walking at times sneakers may be better footware choice than cycling shoes.

6.  Bring a camera has there will be many picture taking opportunities.

7.  Bring a bike lock as we may decide to stop before returning to Lincoln Harbor.

8.  The GPS location for the start of the ride is

Directions to the ride location from Morristown:

·  Route 287 North to Route 80 East

·  Route 80 east to Exit 52 Route 46 East.

·  Route 46 East about 5 miles to Route 3 East.  You want to be in the middle or right hand lane to get on Route 3 East.

·  Route 3 East until last exit in NJ.  Take the exit towards Weehawken and Hoboken.

·  Go about a a quarter mile and then make a right onto Boulevard.

·  After a quarter mile make a left onto Baldwin Ave.

·  Make the first right onto Waterfront Terrace.

·  After 3/10 of a mile make a right onto 19th street.

·  The Sheraton will be on the right.

·  Pull into the parking lot to be ready to start the ride.

For more information please contact Paul  - Email:  [masked].  Advanced sign up by e-mail is not required is appreciated. 

If the weather is questionable the status of hike will be posted on the Yahoo and Meet-up sites.

results.description:
This week we’ll explore VIRTUE, the second of the ten perfections or inherent qualities of the heart.

Generally we define virtue as goodness, ethical integrity, and morality.  In Buddhism this list is expanded with the perfections and includes conducting ourselves wisely, willingness to learn, association with good people, ability and willingness to make corrective actions, willingness to help others, honoring truth, making intentional effort to cultivate and encourage skillful action, being content with what we have, practicing mindfulness and striving for wisdom.

Virtue can also be seen as the quality that synchronizes and balances our hearts and our actions. In our culture we are strongly conditioned to frame virtue in moralistic terms of good and evil; but interestingly, and importantly, Buddhism doesn’t use those distinctions in defining virtue.  Instead, it speaks to the process where our intentions and actions are seen as skillful or unskillful in terms of the positive states they create or the suffering they cause for others or ourselves. 

When we take this more expansive, less judgmental process view and remember that we are responsible for our own actions, we can access and open to our natural courage and curiosity about experiences. We can use any positive or negative outcomes as instructive and refine our course instead of getting stuck in negative states such as guilt or remorse. We find more freedom from suffering when we are living wisely and acting skillfully and in sync with how things really are.


The brief topic discussion will be followed by a guided meditation and time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. I hope you'll join us.


Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds.  The donation box is on the sign-in table.
results.name: The Ten Perfections - Virtue

We were at the Brooklyn Botanical Gardens for the winter, the fall, and spring, the Cherry Blossom Festival and in the summer. Now let's see if we can catch leaves changing color.  It may be too late, or maybe not.  Let's take our chances.

There is free admission to the Brooklyn Botanical Gardens on Saturdays between 10 a.m. and noon. So, while 11 a.m. is rather early, we want to get there for no later than 11 a.m. because if there is a line and the line gets long and we are shooting for closer to noon, we may get blocked out of the free admission.  


We will meet inside the BBG at the gift shop entrance, rather than wait for everyone to then get in line. This is near the Washington Avenue entrance. You can enter the Gardens at the Eastern Parkway entrance, but then you will have to walk towards the Washington Avenue entrance to get to the gift shop. Here's a map to show you what I mean ... http://www.bbg.org/discover/gardens

Bring your cameras!!

results.description:
Join us (3D Systems), OpenBCI, and the MSIT Rapid Prototyping Center for the first ever hackathon at the Mount Sinai Institute of Technology. The focus of the hackathon will be the brain and all of the ways it can be measured and analyzed. With brain-sensing hardware provided by BCI, 3D Printing provided by 3D Systems and the RPC and analysis and design software from IBM, we’ll be building new systems to monitor the brain and modifying some pre-existing ones and then using the outputs to control computers, robotics arms and whatever else we can get our hands (and brains) on.

This is a 2 Day event starting Saturday, November 7th from 11 AM to 7 PM and Sunday, November 8th from 12 PM to 6:00 PM 

Please bring your laptops. For those who do not have 3D Modeling Software Solid Works will be available at the day of the event! Skills recommended to have are 3D modeling and or physical computing skills like Arduino and the code language Processing, everything else you come with is a cherry on top.
results.name: Your Brain + 3D Printing + Sensors = Hackathon!

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.

WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...

1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play elsewhere, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated

9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved

Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.


WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description: Going through volleyball withdrawal? Wednesday nights in the park were great but now that it's dark too early I'm working on a new venue. There's a church that may let us use their gym one night during the week. They are having an open session this Saturday and we're all invited. This particular session is part of their youth program so there will be kids there. If we show up and show what extremely laid back and fun people we are I think they'll be more inclined to let us have the gym one night during the week. So come out and play! As always it'll be fun, free and non competitive. It's from 11-3 but no need to stay for the whole thing. Come anytime.
results.how_to_find_us: Between Broadway and Amsterdam
results.name: Indoor Volleyball!!!!!

results.description:
I have decided to focus this week's session on an emotional issue that many people struggle with: fear.  After our group meditation, I will open with a brief discourse on the topic of fear, why it is so overpowering, where it comes from, and how we can be with the energy of fear.  We will then move into some prayer and mantra work that can help us to move through fear more easily.

We have a beautiful new location to start up the Project Prema Satsang!  The American Buddhist Study Center on the Upper West Side has made available its beautiful library space, which is perfect for meditation, prayer, and discussion.

Start your Saturday with a blissful spiritual gathering!  We'll come together for meditation, contemplation of a short spiritual text, prayer and mantra work, and a heart-opening/active listening practice from Thich Nhat Hanh.  We'll end by sharing what a spiritual path means for each of us, and the challenges we face in opening to unconditional love for ourselves and others.

Given the space considerations, our gathering will be limited to 25 people. To help cover the cost of the room, please consider making a small donation.
results.how_to_find_us: The entrance is on Riverside Drive.  Press the button to ring the 3rd floor.

results.description:
RSVP'ing on Meetup does NOT guarantee entry, you must APPLY TO  JOIN.

----------------------------------


We are excited to announce an opportunity to participate in a unique hands-on experience to join a team and pursue a moonshot idea! TeamX is hosting a 2-day Moonshot Sprint.

>>> TeamX EVENT SITE <<<


When: Saturday & Sunday - November 7th & 8th, 2015

Where: Grand Central Tech accelerator

Who: >>> Apply to attend! <<<

Applications accepted until October 26th.
Selected participants will be notified by October 30th.

Participation is exclusive and awarded through an application process with our selection committee.  We are looking for innovative and curious minds, eager to come form teams and solve some of our toughest challenges.



Additional details about the event will be posted soon!


----------------------------------

Why are we doing this?

Moonshot Sprints will change everything. Moonshot sprints can help form the high impact teams who will pursue ideas that have the potential to become real moonshot projects.

Why is this important?

There are not enough moonshot projects to meet the challenges facing humanity. And in NYC in particular, we have a lot of difficult challenges that require moonshot thinking to resolve.

What’s a moonshot?

A tech moonshot is a radical solution to a difficult challenge, using breakthrough technology.

If you are excited about 10x thinking with science and technology, and if you are looking for a difficult challenge with solutions that have huge scalable implications, then this is where you want to be!


----------------------------------

results.description:
This month we'll discuss "The Martian" by Andy Weir.  This book is about Mark Watney, an astronaut stranded on Mars after a dust storm forces his crew to evacuate thinking him dead.  It is a story of survival and we will read it as a more realistic look at what it would be like to be on Mars in comparison to "A Princess of Mars".  The movie was also released October 2 so if you're interested in reading and seeing for another comparison, we'll discuss that as well at the meeting.


The meeting will be hosted by Wendy at her house in White Plains. We will provide stuffed burgers. Please bring fruit salad, vegetables, potato salad, macaroni salad, appetizers, drinks or desserts. Let everyone know what you will be bringing by commenting on this meeting.

Looking forward to seeing everyone on Saturday, 11/07/2015 at 11:30a.
results.name: Let's discuss "The Martian" by Andy Weir

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, timed it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

Please no fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds will be honored only with a minimum of 24 hour cancelation.  No refunds for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

The school entrance is located on East 109th street between 2nd and 3rd avenues (near 2nd avenue) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right) and someone will open the door for you.

For questions,  use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Its autumn again, and that means its time for our 24 Hour Extra Life Gaming Marathon! Extra Life is a charitable organization that raises money for local hospitals in the Children's Miracle Network. Please visit www.extra-life.org to donate to Team Wildpig, or join the team yourself and get donations from your friends and family.

Join us on November 7-8 from noon to noon as we host video-game tournaments, open board-gaming, and a variety of one-shot RPGs for charity. In addition to donations made online, Wildpig Comics will be donating 25% of its profits for the 24 hour period to Extra Life.

Help spread the word with #extralife and #teamwildpig!

This is the one night a year where store credit will not be accepted due to the charitable nature of the event.

Video Game Tournaments

All Video Game Tournaments will be run one at a time, $5 Entry for 8 Players. They will be single elimination. $20 Store Credit will go to the winner, and $20 per Tournament will go to charity.


• Super Smash Bros for Wii U

• Goldeneye

• Marvel vs Capcom

• Soul Calibur


Board Game Tournaments

All Board Game Tournaments will be run one at a time, $5 Entry for 4 Players. $10 Store Credit will go to the winner, and $10 per Tournament will go to charity.

• DC Deck Builder

• Zombie Dice

• Ghooost!

• Splendor

Magic Tournaments

All Magic Tournaments will be run one at at time, $5 Entry for 8 Players. They will be single elimination. $20 Store Credit will go to the winner, and $20 per Tournament will go to charity.

RPG Events

All RPGs will be $5 Entry. All money raised by these games will be donated to charity. The schedule is as follows:

12-4 AM: The Tomb of Horrors with DM Noah Anderson

4-8 AM:  Fluffyquest 3/Mage Duels with DM Aaron "Chief" Antoine

8 AM-12 PM: Night of 100 Goblins with DM Lewis Mancine

results.description:
Lets explore the Big Apple...

Trip timeline based on taking the 6A MegaBus from North Station. We'll arrive in NYC around 11A which will give us time to check into our hotel and meet at the Clock/Information Booth at Grand Central at noon.

Sites we'll explore include the NY Public Library, Bryant Park, Top of the Rock (3P entry) for sunset (4:45P), Times Square, Flat Iron Bldg, Brooklyn Bridge, DUMBO, Grand Central, and B&H Photo.

Departure time on Sunday 11/8 will be 3P.

Group will be limited to 4, no guests, so we can stay together. Due to limited size of group, please sign up if you can attend and update RSVP should your plans change.

Participants are responsible for transportation, hotel, Top of the Rock tickets, etc.

What to bring - only what you can carry as we will not make stops back at the hotel during the day - mid-range lens, wide angle, tripod, polarizing and neutral density filters.

results.description:
Let's head over to the waterfront for a Northern Thai lunch at Pok Pok NY.  The food is fragrant and full of flavor.   No pad thai or green curry here but instead you'll find their famous fish sauce chicken wings, water spinach with chilies, and Khao Soi noodles.  

I've reserved a table for us.  We will order a number of dishes to share family style. Please be aware that while there are non-spicy dishes on the menu, chilies are common in Northern Thai cooking.  The dishes aren't extremely hot and the meal will be served with sticky rice to help absorb some of that heat.  

Menu


Yelp Reviews

*Please update your rsvp should you're plans change.

*Remember to bring cash to help sort the bill.
results.name: Lunch at Pok Pok NY

results.description:
Note:  This event is being hosted by Dave Cervini's New York Social Network and several of their partner Meet Up Groups.  The number of RSVP listed on this Meet Up reflect only a portion of those attending.  If you have any questions regarding this event, please contact Dave directly at [masked]. 

Central Park is one of the most beautiful parts of New York City!  It is even more stunning as the fall colors are at starting to show below the city skyline.  This opportunity does not last long and there is no better way to experience it than to be with dozens of fun and friendly members of our group plus members of several other social groups! Your guide will share with you the history of the park from its heyday to decline and then rebirth. He will show you amazing pictures  from before the park was there to vintage shots from the late 18 and 1900's.  You will learn of it's construction, design, special secrets and more as the sun shines on a crisp fall day.

The tour lasts about 90 minutes and following the walk you can join us for food and drinks at a local tavern.

Can I come alone? Yes 98% of those attending will come on their own.

What should I wear?  Dress for the weather

What if it rains? We will monitor the weather and send out a final notice by 8am on Saturday morning. Refunds will be sent only if the tour is canceled.

This event is being sponsored by The New York Social Network which is a collaboration of several different Meet Up Groups (www.newyorksocialnetwork.com).  The number of RSVP's below reflect only a portion of those attending.  Please only sign up for this event if you are serious about attending.  We have a 3 flakes and you are out rule!  If you have questions regarding this or other events, please contact the event host Dave Cervini at[masked] or e-mail [masked].
results.name: NY Tours For New Yorkers Central Park Fall Colors & History Tour

venue.name: Outside the 163rd St. station on the C train

results.description:
This walk will be jam-packed with alluring destinations. We'll start by touring the meticulously preserved Jumel Mansion (George Washington's headquarters), and nearby Sylvan Terrace, a picturesque block of 19th-century row houses. Next we'll visit the the Hispanic Heritage Society, featuring El Greco, Goya, Velazquez, and other golden-age masterpieces and impressionist gems. Afterwards we'll tour historic Trinity Cemetery, then walk south through Riverbank and Riverside Parks and warm up at majestic Riverside Church and Grant's Tomb. Next we'll visit the the Nicholas Roerich Museum, filled with mystically inspired paintings, especially of the Himalayas. If it's not too cold we'll finish by walking down to 72nd St. along the scenic Hudson Promenade, hopefully with a spectacular sunset. (Don't worry about the apparently large limit of 110 people--there won't be nearly that many, due to cancellations.)


PLEASE READ THE DETAILS BELOW, SO YOU'RE PROPERLY PREPARED:

DISTANCE: 5 miles to 72nd St., 3 miles to the Roerich Museum.

PACE: Moderate, NOT SLOW. If you want a leisurely stroll rather than a moderate walk, this hike is not for you!

LUNCH: BRING YOUR OWN. We'll eat at around 2:30 PM. Dress warmly enough to sit outdoors for 20 to 30 minutes (depending on the weather) during lunch.

COST: $5 for the Jumel mansion plus $2 for me, in part to cover Meetup's organizer fee. (If you'd rather skip the mansion you can meet us at the Hispanic Society museum, starting around 1:15 PM, inside the courtyard on Broadway between 155th and 156th St.)

ENDING TIME: Around 5:30 PM, but you can leave earlier, of course.

TRANSPORTATION: C train to 163rd St. For more details, consult mta.tripplanner.org as well as a subway map (available online), since the trip planner is  occasionally inaccurate. Be sure to also check this for weekend service changes: http://web.mta.info/weekender/lineview.html
results.how_to_find_us: I'll be wearing a red cap

results.description:
I can board game any time of year but there is something to be said for gaming when it's cold outside.  Particularly fall weather!  A few drinks with good people doesn't hurt either.

Suggested Price of Admission

For $3, the Impact Network can educate a student in Zambia for a month.  With that in mind, I'm going to suggest everyone who comes chip in $3.  What do you get for your money?  Me, my sparkling smile and a giant suitcase full of games to play with for hours.  And with any luck, they'll be spinning vinyl records.  So come, have a beer, meet good people, listen to some funky music and play great games for a good good cause.  I challenge you to find a better deal for three bucks!


                           Four people build a miniature city in Medina

What are we going to play?  I will have at least one new one on tap: "The Hare and Tortise."  Truth is, it's a kids game.  But it looks like a really fun racing game for a group of people.  Each animal in the race (more than just the two from the title) has a special way of moving.  You get secretly assigned one and play cards to move that animal.  First one across the finish line wins!  

Otherwise it'll be the usual fare of games like Medina,  Nuns on the Run, Avalon, Steam Park, Coup...  We'll play relatively simple modern board games that have a quick rules explanation and play in less than an hour.  

What, no Monopoly or Pictionary?  Strategy board and card games have changed, grown and evolved so much over the past decade that they have become wonderful art forms in their own right.  They tell stories and provide new situations for engaging each other in ways that party games or old classics can't.  These modern games wouldn't exist if games like Clue and Taboo hadn't paved the way.  But give the next-gen games a shot and you'll see why I'm so much more excited about new games!


If you're really curious about what I might bring, probe the nerdy depths of my collection and visit my Board Game Geek page.  The bar does have a nice copy of Catan on hand as well.

                   Build your own amusement park in Steam Park

I'm barely getting out of bed when this is starting!  I know that noon on a Saturday is a bit early for people--I get it, believe me--but as long as you show up by 4 (or even 5) you should be able to get some gaming in.

Skylark is a great bar in Park Slope in its own right.  But they are so board game friendly I just had to move our little meetup there.  They have some good bar food but are also open to bringing food as long as we clean up.

Negotiate for the best stock price with up to 11 people in Panic on Wall Street

My phone number is listed near the top of this posting if you have any questions day-of.  And with that we'll see you there!  Or else...

                           Point guns at each other in Ca$h 'n Gun$

results.description:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GpKdTkVACSU

We'll be playing funk this season. Join us for a great time playing in this group. We got the funk of Stevie Wonder, James Brown, Chic, Kool&The Gang, George Clinton and more! 

Acoustic guitars, bass and ukeleles welcome. If electric bring a portable amp:)


This ensemble welcomes ALL LEVELS, so pick your part and let's play! 

To join:

• RSVP before you attend the session.

• Choose your guitar part from TAB>MORE>FILES download/print and bring it to practice to follow. (All charts will be posted by end of August) 

• Bring acoustic guitar or electric with a portable amp. 

• Have an amazing time!

Practice days are:

September 09/05, 09/12, 09/19, 09/26
October 10/03, 10/10, 10/17, 10/24, 10/31 (halloween, boo)
November 11/07, 11/14, 11/21 (skipping Thanksgiving, Happy Thanksgiving!)
December 12/05, 12/12

results.name: Let's Play Funk!

results.description:
I can board game any time of year but there is something to be said for gaming when it's cold outside.  Particularly fall weather!  A few drinks with good people doesn't hurt either.


Suggested Price of Admission

For $3, the Impact Network can educate a student in Zambia for a month.  With that in mind, I'm going to suggest everyone who comes chip in $3.  What do you get for your money?  Me, my sparkling smile and a giant suitcase full of games to play with for hours.  And with any luck, they'll be spinning vinyl records.  So come, have a beer, meet good people, listen to some funky music and play great games for a good good cause.  I challenge you to find a better deal for three bucks! 

            Four people build a miniature city in Medina

What are we going to play?  I will have at least one new one on tap: "The Hare and Tortise."  Truth is, it's a kids game.  But it looks like a really fun racing game for a group of people.  Each animal in the race (more than just the two from the title) has a special way of moving.  You get secretly assigned one and play cards to move that animal.  First one across the finish line wins!  

Otherwise it'll be the usual fare of games like Medina,  Nuns on the Run, Avalon, Steam Park, Coup...  We'll play relatively simple modern board games that have a quick rules explanation and play in less than an hour.  

What, no Monopoly or Pictionary? Strategy board and card games have changed, grown and evolved so much over the past decade that they have become wonderful art forms in their own right.  They tell stories and provide new situations for engaging each other in ways that party games or old classics can't.  These modern games wouldn't exist if games like Clue and Taboo hadn't paved the way.  But give the next-gen games a shot and you'll see why I'm so much more excited about new games! 

If you're really curious about what I might bring, probe the nerdy depths of my collection and visit my Board Game Geek page.  The bar does have a nice copy of Catan on hand as well.

           Build your own amusement park in Steam Park

I'm barely getting out of bed when this is starting! I know that noon on a Saturday is a bit early for people--I get it, believe me--but as long as you show up by 4 (or even 5) you should be able to get some gaming in. 

Skylark is a great bar in Park Slope in its own right.  But they are so board game friendly I just had to move our little meetup there.  They have some good bar food but are also open to bringing food as long as we clean up.

Negotiate for the best stock price with up to 11 people in Panic on Wall Street

My phone number is listed near the top of this posting if you have any questions day-of.  And with that we'll see you there!  Or else...

           Point guns at each other in Ca$h 'n Gun$

results.description:
** UPDATED 10/25/15 **

We will meet inside the Botanical Garden, in front of the Haupt Conservatory.  DO NOT USE THE MEETUP MAP!! USE GOOGLE MAPS INSTEAD!!

Photos from Central Park 2013

Meetup Point relocated to the Haupt Conservatory within the garden. The image below is from our first visit in Spring 2010.

Map of the Garden with the Haupt Conservatory indicated in red.

Website: http://www.nybg.org/

Usually we visit the New York Botanical Garden in the springtime. This year, let's capture some autumn foliage.

Weather permitting, we will meet inside the Botanical Garden, in front of the Haupt Conservatory.  DO NOT USE THE MEETUP MAP!! USE GOOGLE MAPS INSTEAD!!  General admission is $20. Check the website for other pricing. Make sure you ask for a map when you pay.

How to get there by Subway: 

• Take the B, D, or 4 train to Bedford Park Blvd. Station. From the station exit:


• Take the Bx26 bus east to the Garden's Mosholu Gate entrance.


• OR walk eight blocks down the hill on Bedford Park Blvd. (approximately 20 minutes). Turn left onto Southern Blvd. and walk one block to Mosholu Gate entrance.

For directions via Metro North, driving, and parking information, please visit the garden's website.

*****

We may split up into smaller groups.  The botanical garden is huge, so some of you may get lost and/or fall behind.  If you do, don't worry.  Just enjoy the garden and take lots of photos.  We may figure out a secondary meetup point to re-group within the garden.  

*****

From the website regarding Photography:

Plan to Be Outdoors

Most of the Garden consists of outdoor spaces, although there are indoor spaces open year-round as well. The Garden's 250 acres are open in all weather conditions, and a visit can include extensive walking. Please plan your attire accordingly.

Travel Light

The Garden does not have coat-check facilities and certain items are prohibited in various indoor spaces, so plan accordingly.

Photography

Outdoor photography for personal use is allowed, but you must stay on the paths and not disturb the plants and collections. In the Conservatory, photography is permitted with hand-held cameras only. During some exhibitions, photography may be restricted or limited to alleviate crowding and protect the plants. Photography is not permitted in the Art Gallery.

*****


* Be on time! This event starts at 12pm sharp!! So give yourself plenty of time to travel. Check for service changes or delays. I will not wait for latecomers and I will not answer calls, emails and/or messages after 12pm.

* Dress appropriately for the weather and definitely wear comfortable shoes.

* Food and restrooms are located inside the Garden.  Check the map.

Details of this event may be added or changed at any time, so please check in periodically on this page.


If you have any questions, text me, message me (via meetup) or post on this page before the day of the event. Please make sure you identify yourself in your text messages so I know who you are. 


~ Sally 347.878.NYCP (6927) 

******************** 

Disclaimer: Participation in these events requires that you assume all risks associated with these activities, and that the Organizers, Co-Organizers and Event Hosts are in no way liable for any loss or injury as a result of your participation. In other words, you are attending these events at your own risk!! For more details, please review our rules and disclaimers.

Meetup requires a semi-annual fee to organize and maintain the group's event page.  If you would like to send a contribution to help keep NYC Photographers up and running, you can either send $2.00 or more via PayPal at [masked], or you can contribute in cash at an event.  This is NOT a requirement, but any amount will be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

results.description:
HAMILTON HALL, ROOM 503

It's ironic that we live in one of the wealthiest countries in the world, but we always have money problems. We can work hard all our lives but retire poor.


Nobody teaches us how to manage our money in school. Financial issues are not often discussed, and financial products not always explained.

We all want comfortable retirement, but few have a plan. We may be active spenders but passive savers.

We need to change and the task won't be easy. But we need understanding first.

Join us for this life changing presentation. Some concepts to be covered include...

-Building a Financial Foundation

-The Wealth Formula

-The X-Curve

-The Importance of Paying Yourself First

-Simple VS Compunding Interest

& more...

My great friends & I will present a powerful message about how good it feels to own your future instead of fearing it, and what you can do to start taking ownership of yours.

I look forward to meeting all who attend!

results.description:
Come and watch some funny short films during the Big Apple Film Festival Short Film Program, including:

Jackie Boy

In a world morally bankrupt by social media, Jackie Boy doesn't belong. He lurks in the shadows of the streets seeking vengeance on the selfie generation. He is in love with Angie, who isn't like the others--an "angel" he calls her. And when the current superstar of social media beats Jackie for her hand, the ultimate confrontation ensues. Then we learn the truth about our hero.

Mother of the Week

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b4iGhH-5MlI

STACEY (Jennifer Jiles), a 41-year-old career woman has it all together - with the invaluable help of her children's perfect (inside and out) nanny, MARISA (Lexi Zettle), whom the three kids love, and Stacey's husband TIM (Mark Lobene) doesn't mind looking at either. When Marisa takes a week vacation, Stacey is happy to prove herself and reassert her own role as Mom and sexy wife. Easier said than done - Stacey finds that without Marisa's help, taking care of family and work is a little more than she can handle.


Prego

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dLXwKdzSa6Q

Prego is an award-winning short comedy film by Usher Morgan that tells the story of Emily (Katie Vincent), a young woman confronting a one-night stand (Taso Mikroulis) with the revelation that she's pregnant. Things go from bad to worse when Emily discovers that Mark is not an ideal father figure.


Hungry


Kevin is still in love with his ex-girlfriend, Caitlin. When he finds out she is dating a new, rich guy named Jeff, Kevin is heartbroken and wants to win her back. His best friend, Mark, warns Kevin about her, but Kevin is blinded by his love for Caitlin. Kevin believes he has found his answer when he finds a flyer to a burrito eating competition where the winner will win $1,000.

Reefer Man

Lenny Pringle, 65, returns from a two-week visit to his sister in Colorado, greeting his lifelong friend Curly Frye with a hug as he comes to visit. Lenny reveals his plan for 'jumpstarting' his new life: smoking the marijuana he has smuggled back from Colorado. Initially appalled, Curly finally agrees to Lenny's plan, and promises to visit a Head Shop in the morning to purchase items for smoking the weed. The next day, before entering the shop, Lenny reveals that he has made a list of items he wants to buy. Curly is surprised at the extent of the list.... and of Lenny's knowledge! They enter the shop and are greeted by a man named Dusty, who initially thinks they are undercover policemen. Lenny begins to get comfortable with Dusty, but Curly thinks he should not reveal too much about his plan. Curly leaves after Lenny tells him to 'lighten up'. Dusty (his friends call him Zombie), is impressed with Lenny's list, but tantalizes him with talk of showing him some 'new stuff'. They agree that Zombie will bring everything to Lenny's house later that evening. Zombie arrives, and instead of bringing the paraphernalia, he robs them at gunpoint, ties them up and gags them. They manage to remove the gags and call Curly's sister Diane. Diane arrives with her 'friend' Jennifer and they begin to cut the two loose. Lenny is smitten with Jennifer, who helps get a party started after releasing Lenny. After a raucous impromptu party, Lenny and Jennifer become friendlier, and she asks him if he is 'real disappointed ' about losing the drugs. He states that he is not, and that he has devised a new plan: A road trip to Vegas. Jennifer wants to go, but the other are reluctant. They are soon convinced that they should go too. Lenny proclaims that this is where his new life will begin, and they all toast to their big adventure.

Acoustic Space

'Acoustic Space' is a short film about how technology has changed the way we communicate. What Marshall McLuhan once described as a 'global village,' has become a society, if not a world, of people erroneously believing technology is bringing them closer together when in fact it is driving them further and further apart. The film addresses this issue in a funny and satiric way by showing a couple having dinner in an elegant restaurant while all attempts at conversation are constantly interrupted by their ringing cell phones.

HOW TO BUY? Tickets are available online: http://www.eventbrite.com/e/program-26-tickets-18713951934

Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
• “The greatest deception [people] suffer is from their own opinions.”

                   --Leonardo da Vinci


People often talk about how others are self-deluded, not “correctly” seeing “reality,” misinterpreting information and facts. But what if we’re all self-deluded and we just don’t know it? (Or maybe we’re self-deluded about how well we can assess our self-delusions!) Well, for one night, we will deliberate, discuss, debate, and challenge each other to consider these and other related considerations about self-delusion. In particular, we will explore the ways in we (unknowingly) deceive ourselves, some cognitive and emotional reasons why we do this, and possible ways we can counteract these tendencies. Some of the questions we will consider include, but are not limited to:


· Why do people believe weird things?

· How can our prior knowledge both help and hinder our perceptions and interpretations of new experiences? · How is it possible that the same cognitive processes—such as drawing inferences and making conclusions, synthesizing information from various sources, and analyzing and evaluating information—lead us to both “accurate” and “reliable” knowledge and also misunderstandings and misconceptions? · Is it possible to know when and how we are deceiving ourselves? Is it even possible for us to see ourselves more clearly?

· What counteractive strategies might help us to see ourselves, others, and the world around us more accurately and reliably?

Structure of the Discussion:

We will start by defining and establishing what self-delusion means and what examples of it could be. (It would be great if you could bring some real-life examples of people who you think have deluded themselves, or, even better, personal examples!)

We will then discuss why and how people delude themselves.

We will consider whether and how we can counteract these cognitive tendencies.

We will reflect on the implications and applications of our discussion for our lives and the lives of those around us. We will make conscientious efforts and an official commitment to delude ourselves less and less everyday! About the Moderator:

Rolando is an educator of educators. He works with teachers from the four major disciplines—Math, Science, English, and History—to craft, hone, and assess their pedagogical practices. He has hosted other discussion groups on Meetup. In his spare time, he enjoys reading, writing, and ruminating on how often he engages in self-deception. . . .


VENUE: Bread and Butter, (Corner of E. 29 St and Park South)
results.name: "How Do We Deceive Ourselves? Is It Possible to See Ourselves More Clearly?"

results.description:
SCAVENGER HUNT AT THE MUSEUM


Saturday, November 7, 2015
1:00 PM

American Museum of Natural History
Central Park West at 79th Street, New York, NY (edit map)

NY - The Murder at the Museum of Natural History Scavenger Hunt

All tickets include admission to the museum. There are no special ticket types or discounts for museum members. Early Bird pricing applies to purchases made by noon on the Wednesday before the hunt.
The hunt is played on teams of two to six people. Someone, or something, has been bumping off museum staffers involved in acquiring a sacred Egyptian relic. Is it the dreaded Curse of Ahtchu? Or is a serial killer on the loose? Your team of sleuths will have to crack a hieroglyphic code and uncover the museum's secrets to stop the killings. For murder hunts, we strongly recommend hunting with a team of three or more. If you sign up with fewer than three people, we suggest pairing up with others at the start of the hunt to form a larger team. Early bird adult $42 https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pe.c/10024209

Gallery Hop - Saturday, November 7, 2015 - 1PM!

We’re doing another of our ever popular Gallery Hops, this one in the well established west side photo gallery district of Chelsea with PWCC and our own Rita Russo. We’ll be revisiting and walking through the area to see what’s happening and combine our hopping (from gallery to gallery) with some actual shooting in the neighborhood.  We’ll meet in front of the Dallas BBQ Restaurant on the North West corner of Eighth Avenue and 23rd Street (the C and E trains stop right on the corner and the #1 train is just a block away). Let’s meet at 1 PM so we can start shooting and hopping with plenty of daylight.   A list of galleries and approximate times of our visit will be distributed and published here as well.  Bring your camera if you would like to do some shooting along the way or after.  The nearby Highline has been extended to 34th Street and the new #7 Westside Javits Ctr station has opened.

results.description:
Hi Folks, based on our Doodle survey we've set a date and time for our first meetup! Please note that although the Doodle was for noon the meetup will be at 1PM as we've been warned that any earlier will be difficult due to weekend brunch rush. That's Saturday, November 7 at 1PM. Mark your calendars! I'll send out another reminder closer to the date because, if you're anything like me, it's impossible to remember anything planned that far in advance. 

Anyone who has Rheumatoid Arthritis or wants to support a loved one with the disease is welcome to join us. Feel free to spread the word to anyone you know who would benefit from our group. Just give us a heads up if you're bringing additional folks so we know how many people to fit in at our table. 

Looking forward to meeting all of you!

results.description:
Here's an awesome complimentary class on Saturday, November 7th (in less than 2 weeks) that we highly recommend!   Make sure to put it on your calendar. 


A LIVE FREE Online Event– 6 NEW Brain & Mindset Experts–LATEST Cutting Edge & Evidence Based Methodologies, Tools & Technologies to re-train your brain and "Shatter Your Financial Glass Ceiling". 

This year’s Live Brain-A-Thon will be hosted by brain expert and star of the Secret, John Assaraf, and he will be joined by 6 other experts in the field of neuroscience, neuropsychology and neuroplasticity. 

Here are the experts and a summary of the topics they’ll cover:

 - Dr. Daniel Amen - Change Your Brain, Change Your Income 
- Sharon Pearson- From Suicide to $10 Million a Year 
- Dr. David Kruger - How to Change your Money Story 
- Dr.Heidi Hanna- Eliminate Stress and Worries about Money  
- Mark Waldman - Unshackle the Chains of Your Past: letting go of past failures, traumas or events that are keeping you stuck  
- Dr. Srini Pillay - Harvard Professor and past Brain-A-Thon guest 

Reserve your place for this incredible free live video web cast, on Saturday, November 7th @ 1pm - 9pm EST: 

Signup at http://www.nypt.info/brainathon 

----------------------------------------------------------

Do you ever feel like there's an invisible barrier preventing you from reaching your lifestyle and wealth goals? 


Well, the world's top neuroscientists and brain experts say ... you're right! 

You see, your brain is split into two parts: Your rational logical mind and your implicit emotional brain... and the emotional brain is the larger and far more powerful of the two! 

If your emotional desires, beliefs and values don't align with your rational mind's goals ... the two parts of your mind will constantly be fighting each other and undermining your ability to succeed at anything, especially your lifestyle goals. 

Scientists now know that you will NEVER outperform your own internal hidden limiting self-image. Your current results are nothing more than old neural patterns, beliefs, perceptions and habits that you've accumulated over your life that drives all your thoughts and actions. 

But brain scan studies have PROVEN something really exciting...

You can re-wire and re-train the key areas in your brain that control your conscious thoughts AND subconscious feelings and emotions that influence every decision and action you take. 

This requires applying the right brain-training methodologies and technologies in the right way... so you can replace limiting beliefs, behaviors, and habits that are currently keeping you stuck. 

And that's precisely what 6 of the top neuroscientists and brain experts are teaming up to help you do during a historic virtual event on Saturday, November 7th... 

Join John Assaraf, who you may recognize from the hit movie The Secret, and 6 of the world's top neuroscientists and brain experts who are gathering to teach you how to apply the right brain training methodologies and technologies in the right way... so you can replace limiting beliefs, behaviors, and habits that are currently keeping you stuck. 

Here are the experts and a summary of the topics they’ll cover:

 - Dr. Daniel Amen - Change Your Brain, Change Your Income

- Sharon Pearson - From Suicide to $10 Million a Year

- Dr. David Kruger - How to Change your Money Story 

-Dr. Heidi Hanna - Eliminate Stress and Worries about Money - 

-Mark Waldman - Unshackle the Chains of Your Past: letting go of past failures, traumas or events that are keeping you stuck

- Dr. Srini Pillay - Harvard Professor and past Brain-A-Thon guest 

They'll teach you how to get your brain in coherence with your lifestyle goals...and keep you there! No more yoyo-ing around and starting and stopping your success. 

Reserve your place for this incredible free live video web cast, on Saturday, November 7th @ 1pm: 

http://www.nypt.info/brainathon

results.description:
Workshop Topic Details:

Hands-On Exploit Development

Want to write memory corruption vulnerabilities but don’t know where to start? Do you secretly aspire to Pwn2Own glory and a life as a freelance bug hunter? So many tutorials assume a certain amount of previous knowledge, or the example programs are so hard to find and setup so you can follow along.

This workshop tackles the basics of how memory corruption vulnerabilities work as well as helping you get familiar with the tools of the trade such as Immunity Debugger, WinDBG, and Mona.py. Using real vulnerable programs in a contained lab environment, this hands-on class will get you up to speed on the basics in preparation for further study in this exciting realm.

Instructor Bio:

We're excited to have Georgia Weidman as our guest instructor. Shevirah founder and CEO Georgia Weidman is a serial entrepreneur, penetration tester, security researcher, speaker, trainer, and author. She holds a MS in computer science as well as holding CISSP, CEH, and OSCP certifications. Her work in the field of smartphone exploitation has been featured internationally in print and on television. She has provided training at conferences such as Blackhat USA, Brucon, and Security Zone. Georgia founded Bulb Security LLC, a security consulting firm specializing in security assessments/penetration testing, security training, and research/development. She was awarded a DARPA Cyber Fast Track grant to continue her work in mobile device security culminating in the release of the open source project the Smartphone Pentest Framework (SPF).

She founded Shevirah Inc. to create product solutions for assessing and managing the risk of mobile devices in the enterprise and testing the effectiveness of enterprise mobility management solutions and is a graduate of the Mach37 cybersecurity accelerator. She is the author of Penetration Testing: A Hands-On Introduction to Hacking from No Starch Press. She was the recipient of the 2015 Women’s Society of CyberJutsu Pentest Ninja award.

For Every Workshop:

This is a hands-on workshop where you will put into practice those things you may have read about or covered in a class. This is also a great opportunity to meet other like-minded women and to keep your skills fresh if you're a veteran! You will also earn continuing education credits towards your certification renewal.

Every workshop progresses from beginner through advanced topic material. Beginners are encouraged to watch and learn as much as possible even though you might not have a clue. Exposure to new tools and techniques by watching will advance your learning process a lot more quickly than trying to learn on your own. You will get to ask questions and see how it's done in the real world. Advanced attendees are encouraged to share their knowledge and experience and help answer "noob" questions as much as possible.

Agenda:

1200 - 100: Set-up, introductions, and lunch (included)

100 - 600:  Training

(Please note that this will be active workshop time - if you have not completed set-up it will be challenging to follow along.)

Prerequisites:

Basic IT knowledge.

A good attitude and willingness to learn.

Remote and Male Associate Member Participation:

Register online. Once registered, you'll receive the meeting participation info by email the day before the workshop. Expect to join 15-30 minutes prior to test your technical configurations.

Prep Requirements:

Laptop with tools installed. Details will be posted soon.

Cost:

Full/Student/Military Member:  $35

Associate Member and Remote Attendee: $15

CTA Member:  FREE with code

Free (non-paying) Member: $50

YOU MUST REGISTER ON THE WEBSITE HERE

Thank you to our venue sponsor: Launch Workplaces

FOR THOSE WHO WILL BE IN NYC - The get together at iMentor scheduled for Nov. 7th has been cancelled.

If you have any questions please contact Pamela Dean at: [masked]

https://womenscyberjutsu.org/resource/resmgr/Images/launchworkplaces.PNG

results.description:
*Check out CNY's first Kickstarter Campaign!

----

“The greatest deception [people] suffer is from their own opinions.” 

                                                        --Leonardo da Vinci

People often talk about how others are self-deluded, not “correctly” seeing “reality,” misinterpreting information and facts.  But what if we’re all self-deluded and we just don’t know it?  (Or maybe we’re self-deluded about how well we can assess our self-delusions!) 

Well, for one night, we will deliberate, discuss, debate, and challenge each other to consider these and other related considerations about self-delusion. 

In particular, we will explore the ways in we (unknowingly) deceive ourselves, some cognitive and emotional reasons why we do this, and possible ways we can counteract these tendencies. 

Some of the questions we will consider include, but are not limited to:

·  Why do people believe weird things?

·  How can our prior knowledge both help and hinder our perceptions and interpretations of new experiences? 

·  How is it possible that the same cognitive processes—such as drawing inferences and making conclusions, synthesizing information from various sources, and analyzing and evaluating information—lead us to both “accurate” and “reliable” knowledge and also misunderstandings and misconceptions? 

·  Is it possible to know when and how we are deceiving ourselves? Is it even possible for us to see ourselves more clearly?

 ·  What counteractive strategies might help us to see ourselves, others, and the world around us more accurately and reliably?

Structure of the Discussion:

We will start by defining and establishing what self-delusion means and what examples of it could be.  (It would be great if you could bring some real-life examples of people who you think have deluded themselves, or, even better, personal examples!)

We will then discuss why and how people delude themselves.

We will consider whether and how we can counteract these cognitive tendencies.

We will reflect on the implications and applications of our discussion for our lives and the lives of those around us. 

We will make conscientious efforts and an official commitment to delude ourselves less and less everyday! 

About the Moderator:

Rolando is an educator of educators.  He works with teachers from the four major disciplines—Math, Science, English, and History—to craft, hone, and assess their pedagogical practices.  He has hosted other discussion groups on Meetup.  In his spare time, he enjoys reading, writing, and ruminating on how often he engages in self-deception. . . .


VENUE:  Bread and Butter, (Corner of E. 29 St and Park South)
results.name: "How Do We Deceive Ourselves? Is It Possible to See Ourselves More Clearly?"
