results.description:
Flag Football Game at Cunningham Park (196th St and Union Turnpike) in Queens. Come out and join us!

We have cones and flags so all you need is cleats if that is what you prefer. GAMES WILL ALWAYS BE PLAYED REGARDLESS OF THE WEATHER CONDITIONS i.e. rain, snow, cold, mud, ice, storm, hurricane, etc...we never cancel games due to weather...games are fun and competitive, all skill levels are welcome, please contact me if you have any questions.

NOTE: PLEASE RSVP "YES" ONLY IF YOU ARE GOING TO SHOW UP TO THE GAME.  YOU CAN CHANGE YOUR RSVP IF SOMETHING COMES UP (OR IF YOU DON'T WANT TO PLAY IF IT'S TOO COLD/IT'S RAINING/IT'S SNOWING) AND YOU CAN'T MAKE IT.  NO-SHOWS WILL BE REMOVE FROM THE GROUP.  IT IS IMPORTANT TO HAVE AN ACCURATE HEAD COUNT SO WE KNOW HOW MANY PEOPLE ARE REALLY COMING.

ere are some of the new changes we have made and a reminder of some of the guidelines we already have:

1) You can not add  guests to your RSVP.  Anyone is free to come and play IF AND ONLY IF you have a profile in meetup and have joined our group.  It's 100% FREE to join and it only takes about 2 minutes to sign up and RSVP.  There are also FREE mobile apps for iPhones and Android phones so you can RSVP easily on the go.  If any of your friends has been playing and wants to continue to play, ask them to go to http://www.meetup.com/Cunningham-Park-Football/ and sign up and RSVP individually.  YOU CAN NOT PLAY if you're not signed up and RSVPd.

2) The first 20 people that RSVP for the game, will play a 9-on-9 game with 1 sub.  Everyone on the waiting list will pick players and play against the winner of the game.  Games will be to 2 scores.  If a team gets 2 scores, with the score 2-1, the other team gets one (1) more possession to try to score and tie the game.  If the game is tied again, the game is now to 3 points and the same rule applies, once one of the teams gets score #3, the other team gets just one (1) more possession to try to tie the game.  If 20 or less players show up to the game, game can be played to whatever score everyone agrees to.

3) If you're one of the first 20 to RSVP, but you're late, the next person on the waiting list that's present on the field will take your place and play in the first game.

4) On a safety, ball stays at the goal line and the next down will be played.  For example: If a 2nd down play is ran and a safety occurs, the ball stays at the goal line and the 3rd down will be played.

5) On an OBVIOUS "Defensive Pass interference", the ball will stay at the line of scrimmage but you reset your plays and start at 1st down again.  For example: If a 3rd down play is ran and a DPI occurs, the ball stays at the line of scrimmage and a 1st down will be played, then 2nd, then 3rd...etc.

6) On an OBVIOUS "Offensive Pass interference", the ball stays at the line of scrimmage and the offensive time will lose a down.  For example: If a 2nd down play is ran and an OPI occurs, the offensive team will now be on a 4th down situation from the line of scrimmage.

7) As you might have noticed we have had very few injuries (knock on wood) throughout the years.  This is why we wanted to remind you of the following:

-Stiff arming, flag guarding and hand slapping are NOT ALLOWED.

-Blocks from the back are NOT allowed ad they're obviously dangerous and can cause injuries.

-VERY IMPORTANT: If you are the offensive player and have the ball in your hands, you MUST avoid contact and CAN NOT under any circumstances lower your shoulders and try to initiate contact with an defensive player.  This is flag football, if you're looking for a different type of game there are plenty of other places and leagues to play flag or full-contact football.

8) Donations:  I pay the monthly fee for hosting these meetups and never charge anyone.  All we asked for you is to drop at least $1 in the container we have set up for this, all the money is used for equipment, flags, cones, etc.  You can click on "Group Tools > Money" and see where all the money is going.  If we buy anything with that money we record the transaction and upload a picture of the receipt of whatever equipment we bought.  Next thing we want to get are end zone weighted pylons and we want to buy orange rope so we can mark the field faster and more accurately to avoid any arguments about where the first down is or what not.

IMPORTANT: WE ARE ALL ADULTS AND OBVIOUSLY CAN'T FORCE ANYONE TO DO ANYTHING.  WE NEED EVERYONE'S COOPERATION TO FOLLOW THESE SIMPLE GUIDELINES TO KEEP THE GAME FUN AND COMPETITIVE.  IF FOR ANY REASON YOU DISAGREE OR BELIEVE THAT THESE GUIDELINES DO NOT FIT YOUR STYLE OF PLAY OR WHAT YOU'RE LOOKING FOR ON A PICK-UP GAME, YOU'RE WELCOME TO PLAY WITH A DIFFERENT MEETUP GROUP OR IN ANY OTHER PICK-UP GAME...NO HARD FEELINGS.

If you have any suggestions, questions or concerns, please feel free to reach me at[masked] or [masked]

Regards,

Carlos

results.description:
This event is proudly brought to you by Soccer Beyond!

Learn more on SoccerBeyond.com or Facebook.com/SoccerBeyond.

Details - Fun, interactive, effective.

90min. This is a Coed Soccer Lesson. Please bring a ball if you have. Sneakers, running and turf shoes are fine. Bring some water or sports drink and maybe sun blocker. Please note our Waiver of Liability and 24hr Cancellation Policy below. More details follow.

Rain or Shine - If you don't hear from us, the session is on!

Our sessions will be held as scheduled if weather allows. Thunder or snow and ice are among the reasons for sessions to be canceled/ moved. BUT: Don't make assumptions - you will always get notified if a class is canceled/ moved. As the weather changes quickly in NYC, occasionally we may make the final decision about 90min prior to session start. If you don't hear from us, the session is on!

Cancelled/ Moved Sessions - You will always get notified!

Every time we have to cancel a session, if possible, we move it to the same day and time of the following week. In this case, all players keep their spots. Please email us prior to the rescheduled event, if you can't make and wish a refund or credit. The 24 hours cancellation policy applies. You will always get notified if a class is canceled/ moved.

Requesting a Refund

To request a refund 1) change your status to "not going" and 2) send us a note with the Paypal transaction number related to the payment for the respective session. Refunds are processed once a week - please be patient.


24 Hours Cancellation Policy

A full refund/ credit will be given if cancellation is received at least 24 hours prior to lesson start. Full payment is required thereafter. Our cancellation policy also applies to package holders.


Waiver of Liability and Hold Harmless Agreement

By RSVP'ing for this event you certify that you are physically fit such as you are able to participate in this program. You therewith voluntarily release CoachFrankNYC/ Soccer Beyond, LLC from any and all liability resulting from or arising out of your participation and/ or receipt of instruction. You read and agree to the WAIVER OF LIABILITY AND HOLD HARMLESS AGREEMENT to be found on SoccerBeyond.com/pages/waiver.

Please let us know if you have any questions or suggestions.

Coach Frank  
M. [masked]

results.description:
THREEFOLD FLAME WORKSHOP

Do you wish to open your heart to love in your life and for yourself?  Are you seeking the joy within yourself that makes your heart sing every day?

Come and spend a day with Ishtar working with the threefold flame that holds your love, light and the wisdom of your being. Learn how to align to the energies of your Divine Self so that you can bring love into your life at a deeper and profound level.

Ishtar is the sacred Keeper of the threefold Flame and has been working with the Ascended Masters as an embodied channel for the past 13 years to anchor this work on the Earth. During this time she co-created with the Ascended Masters a self-mastery program called the Masters Way, which is the embodiment of the threefold flame consciousness - Path of Light, Path of Love and Path of Mystery.

With the Masters Ishtar has written three manuals (each approx. 355 pages) of wisdom and light. Each path is an initiation of the self to align and anchor the masculine, feminine and Christed flames within you. This work is now being taught around the world - England, Switzerland, Australia, Mexico and USA. Classes will be starting in the NY/NJ area in January 2016 with Julie Connor, Gale Haas, and Janet Amato. 

Ishtar and the Ascended Masters will share with you over this day what is the threefold flame of God consciousness within you and how you can access this every day. They will support you to understand how this consciousness works in your life to direct you to make the choices that you make to create the reality that you live.

They will teach you how to align the twin flame - masculine and feminine consciousness - within you so that you can attract meaningful relationships in your life that will bring joy and support you to be all that you can be.

Over this day you will learn so much more about the feminine and masculine consciousness of your being and the consciousness that humanity has mastered on the Earth and what it is now being called to master in this new age.

Some of this information is new and it will surprise you and delight you, while some may even question what you have already learned or read. But we can guarantee that you will walk away with a new understanding of the consciousness of God that resides in you and how you are being asked to manifest this on the Earth as your living truth.

COST: $125

TO RESERVE YOUR SEAT PLEASE CONTACT: Gale Haas: Phone: [masked] 

In’Easa mabu Ishtar is an international spiritual teacher and counselor. She is an embodied Ascended Master Channel who has worked with the Masters for the past 10 years, regularly channeling high frequency wisdom teachings for groups and individuals.

Ishtar was guided and directly taught to open her pillar of light initially by Saint Germain, then Serapis Bey, Kuthumi, Mother Mary and Maitreya, Presently, she is working directly with Maitreya and Mary Magdalene to awaken the God (Christ) Consciousness on the Earth.
results.name: Three Fold Flame Workshop - Light, Love and Wisdom with Ishtar

group.name: The Light Within Us- A Spiritually Illuminated Community

results.description:
We had a modest sized but enthusiastic group in October, which included new members Nicole and Chris and their 7 month old puppy Reggie. Reggie had a great time playing with a Boston terrier puppy who was on site.

Next month we're having our annual Cairntucky Derby, otherwise known as "that chaotic Cairn race". When the dog run clears out some (usually around 10:15 or so) we'll put the entrants along one line and their owners some distance away along another line, release the dogs on signal, and see who gets to their waiting owners first. You can call your dog but no treats or toys are allowed. We'll have prizes for the first three finishers.

Each entrant will need a handler for the start. If you're coming solo don't despair. You can probably draft an extra hand either from among our members or their guests or from others present in the dog run.

If you think your Cairn only has eyes for you, he'll be put to the test when you ask him to come when surrounded by other temptations and distractions.

If you or your guests can shoot videos, we'd love to have one or more videos of the race.

Make-up date is the following Sunday (11/15), same time, same place.
results.name: Third Annual Cairntucky Derby and Romp

Who's ready to do something fun & different? A Pub Crawl for Juice...experience a hangover that leaves you feeling healthy & energized! 

What is a Juice Crawl? 

It's a fun, social and healthy living event similar to a traditional pub crawl except we workout and travel to juice bars. Hang with fellow juice lovers, yogis, runners, health conscious individuals etc... Anyone is welcome! 

1 TICKET COVERS IT ALL: 
Sample 20 + different types of juices. 
Free Yoga Class. 
Total value = over $100

*Tickets for our group are just $40 until Oct 18th. $57 after or save 10% when you bring a friend w/ discount code "10" (discount only good at $57 price level w/ friend).

*Must purchase ticket in advance at this link to attend - http://dljparty.ticketleap.com/juice-crawl/

9:30am check in 
10:00am yoga

we should end before 2pm

DESCRIPTION:


Whether you want to play competitively, hit around, or even just check out the hot guys and girls, you've come to the right place. I will try to host the badminton events on bi-weekly basis in order to provide you with an badminton experience where you can get your daily exercise in, improve at the game of badminton, and socialize with other fellow badminton-ers, all at the same time!

After the badminton event, we will have lunch together at Flushing.


To have a good play experience, we will put a cap of  10 on the attendee.
Please only RSVP when you are sure you will show up.

WEAR:
Sport cloth and sneaker.

BRING:
Badminton racquets and birdies, bottles of water, towel and clothes to change.
PS.If you don't have a badminton racquet, you can rent one at the center for $4 per day and $20 deposit.

LOCATION:
New York Badminton Center,[masked]th Ave, Flushing, NY 11354 ( enter 34th Ave from College Point Blvd )
New York Badminton Center (NYBC) is designated badminton facility with 6 international tournament standard Badminton floor mats on top of 3″ high wood floor elevation for maximum shock absorbing and pressure reduction to knees and ankles.  Center also equipped with Table Tennis, Weights room, kids room, and spacious resting area, large bathrooms. Center opens 7 days all year around. It offers the convenience for players to play on any of the days they prefer. Center is close to public transportation (about 10 mins walking), street parking is also available.   

For more info about NY Badminton Center, check the link in the reference section below. 


TRANSPORTATION:
Subway: #7 train to Main St. Station, 10-13 min walk.



REFERENCE LINK:

• http://newyorkbadmintoncenter.com/

DISCLAIMER:

http://www.meetup.com/NYCAsianMeetup/pages/Disclaimer

results.description:
Finally. After much begging and pleading by my loyal game players, it's time to play Flag football. Hut, hut, hike!

If you don’t know, now you know…

Flag football is a version of American football where the basic rules of the game are similar to those of the mainstream game, but instead of tackling players to the ground, the defensive team must remove a flag or flag belt from the ball carrier ("deflagging") to end a play. The emphasis of the game is its recreational, non-contact nature.  We all have good-paying jobs that we need to return to on Monday morning without injury, so anyone looking to channel their inner Lawrence Taylor should find another game to play in. This game is all skill level and gender friendly, so women and those with two left feet and ten thumbs are encouraged to join.

The game can be played a number of ways and the rules of my specific event will be explained before we play, but I base my rules on the WAKA league playing guide. Take a read before game time HERE.

A $3.00 organization fee will be collected at this event, your host is in the running for hardest working person on meetup.

The important stuff...

• This is a co-ed game so ladies don't be shy to sign up. And it doesn't matter if you have no athletic ability; you just have to be willing to have a little fun.

• Dress for physical activity! You'll be running A LOT so wear your sneaks, shorts and a t-shirt. Cleats are NOT allowed.

• Bring BOTH a black and white t-shirt. This is how we differentiate teams.

• Rain or similar un-favorable weather cancels the meetup.

• Check the meetup site before leaving for last minute
updates as well as my mobile phone number.

• No guests allowed to play. You can bring a friend to spectate though if you need to hear the roar of the crowd.

• Please DO NOT RSVP if you do not seriously plan to attend as space is limited. No flakes allowed! If you RSVP and I notice that you have a number of no shows or have a history of last minute cancellations, you will be removed.
results.name: Urban Athletics: Flag Football (Co-ed)

THE GAME: Informal Meet Up 7vs7  

This game is ideally for INTERMEDIATE to ADVANCED players,NOT for BEGINNERS. Please bring GOOD ATTITUDE.  

RSVP GUIDELINES: IMPORTANT:  You must be on the RSVP list to play. If you are not. If you RSVP and don't show, you'll be removed from the group for 4 weeks.

PLAY GUIDELINES:

• We usually play for 90 - 120 minutes. with a short water break half time in. Please don't come if you can't play at least 90 minutes

• We play with 6 feet wide pop-up goals 

• No slide tackles. Turf shoes are suggested.

• Respect your teammates and opponents. 

RECOMMENDED GEAR - Turf shoes and no shinguards necessary

ABOUT THE FIELD - We always play on Turf fields

**INJURIES & DISCLAIMER**: Group Organizer(s) and Group Organization Assumes NO Risk Or individual Liability For Personal Injuries Incurred By Members/Players On The Field Or During Any Of Our Activities: Pick Up Games, Or Other Events. By Agreeing To Play, You Are In Receipt Of This Information, And Thereby Warrant That You Are In Good Health And Assume Personal Responsibility For ALL Physical And Accidental Risks Involved With Playing In Our Group, Including But Not Limited to Falls, Injuries, Contact With Other Players, and Field Conditions.

results.description:
LEADER: Peter Reiner ([masked] or[masked])

RATING: B 6.5 B

Meet at the Hiker Parking area on Rt. 106 where the SBM crosses (opposite Beaver Pond Camp Ground Entrance) at 10 AM . We shuttle over to the Lake Skannatati parking area to start. We will hike on the Long Path to the SBM back to Beaver Pond, going over the Jackie Jones Mt. fire tower. Rain cancels hike.  TC Southern Harriman map 118.

*   *   *   *   *   *

Our full hike schedule can be viewed on our website at hudsonhikers.org, and some hikes are also posted on our Facebook page.

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities.  Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance. 

Pace Ratings: 
     A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster 
     B = Moderate - about 2 mph 
     C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less 

Distance:Noted in miles 

Terrain Ratings:
     A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents, 
             possible rock scrambling
     B = Moderate climbs and descents
     C = Generally flat with little elevation change 

For example, a hike rated “B-7-A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling. 

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike. 

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

NO SHOW/LATE CANCELLATION POLICY:
Please be considerate of event hosts/organizers and others who may want to attend an event by not being a "NO SHOW" (failing to show up when you've RSVP'd "yes") or a "LATE CANCEL" (changing RSVP to a "no" within 24 hours of an event).  If you have a history of No Shows and/or Late Cancels, we may have to bump you to the waiting list for meetups with limited space, in favor of those with a positive attendance history.

results.description:
Don't miss our last Jets tailgate of the season (last 2 sold out!)

Join 40 Meetup members for a traditional all-inclusive tailgate party with food & drink before the game... PLUS YOU WILL GO ONTO THE FIELD before the game!  No other group has an offer like this!  If you are a fan or not, seeing a live NFL football game in person is an awesome experience!

Our tailgate party in the parking lot begins at 10am! If you have never tailgated before, it is one of the most unique people watching and social experiences you will ever have.

We'll have burgers, dogs, chicken wings, sausage & peppers, chips, soda, beer, wine and all the fixings you need to get ready for the game. We will also make a vegetarian selection for those who would like.

$120 Includes: ticket to game, all-inclusive tailgate party with food, drinks, & a special on-field opportunity! This will sell out quickly so get your tickets today!!

*This is a PREPAY ONLY EVENT.  Get your tickets here - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/jets/dates/Nov-08-2015_at_1000AM

*20+ members already prepaid and less than 20 tickets left!  (Pic below from last year's Meetup on the field!)

How do I get there? You can get to the stadium yourself and meet us at tailgate or meet the group near Penn Station and head out together via NJ Transit. There will be a group leaving the city meeting at Starbucks on 7th Ave and 31st St at 8:30am for those who wish to travel out together.

Where is the tailgate? Tailgate is in the Orange lot across from IZOD Center. To help find the tailgate, you can also contact the event organizer (Dave) at[masked]

Can I come alone? Yes, 90% of those attending will be coming on their own.

Where are the Seats? The seats will be in the upper section of the stadium in the end zone 322, stacked row to row so that you can talk to others in the group.

Who will attend?  A mix of fans and non fans, both men and women. This is non-age/ethnic specific and tickets are non-refundable.

What to wear? Be comfortable & casual. Rain or shine event.

There does not seem to be a lot of people registered on this Meet Up, are there more people going? Yes, this event is being promoted by several Meet Up groups and we'll have 40 members attending.

How do I attend? Purchase a ticket for the NY Jets vs Jacksonville Jaguars game & tailgate here - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/jets/dates/Nov-08-2015_at_1000AM
results.how_to_find_us: Tailgate location will be sent to you after ticket is purchased, closer to event date

venue.name: Van Cortlandt Park at 242nd St & Broadway in the Bronx

results.description:
6 miles on trail in Van Cortland Park with guest host Pinky the Pacer!!!

Where:  Meet at the 242nd St. Van Cortlandt Park 1 station. Outside, on the Van Cortlandt Park side of Broadway.

Trail Details: Pinky leads the way through the trails in Van Cordlandt. We’ll run two 3 mile loops. These are mild trails, good for beginners. All paces welcome, slow or fast Pinky's got your back ;)

Via pubic transit: Take the 1 train to 242nd Street Van Cortland Park. By Car: Put Van Cortlandt Park 242 St, Bronx, NY in your GPS.

Bag Drop/Etc: Pinky’s driving to the location, so you can drop you bag in her car while we run. Post trail, we head to the Bronx Ale House for brunch. 

——————————————————————————


In addition Pinky is promoting the Dirty Bird 15k trail race on November 29th. Ride on the Pinky Party Bus to and from the race. Email Pinky for more info: [masked]
#pinkyspack
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be wearing BTR shirts, looking like trail runners and hanging out with Pinky.
results.name: Trail bRUNch! (with Pinky the Pacer)

results.description:
Please Buy Your Ticket ($15) at: http://tinyurl.com/qe8f69r

WORKSHOP LEADER: Patricia Bauer (Marymount School)


Part 1: Whiteboard as a Verb: Whether you are a modeler or not, the benefits of whiteboarding are multitudinous. Whiteboarding stimulates collaborative interactions among small groups of students, allows students to develop skills in articulating both probing questions and clear, concise explanations, promotes critical thinking skills, creates room for demonstrating understanding using pictures rather than words. Teachers and students are able to assess student mastery of concepts, model development, operational definitions and problem-solving skills in a low stakes environment. Patricia Bauer will share some whiteboarding strategies she has found useful and she will encourage participants to share their own strategies and to work together to discover innovative uses of whiteboards in any classroom.

Part 2: Expanding Your Resource Bank: Have you ever googled a term or looked for a  “better way” to do a lab or explain a concept, particularly for students who are struggling in your class and needs an alternative approach/explanation? Or maybe you have a student who has been absent and is trying to catch up? Or maybe you want to encourage a student to “take it to the next level”. You could spend hours vetting sites. During the second part of this workshop, teachers are encouraged to be prepared to share some of the resources they have discovered and have found useful (including any accompanying worksheets for a particular movie/animation/lab). Through the workshop, you will learn strategies to make your students active participants in the learning process and gain a list of resources vetted by your colleagues.

WHO SHOULD COME TO THIS WORKSHOP?

· Anyone interested in learning about how to use whiteboards to engage students in the learning process as well as those interested in gaining and sharing teaching resources.

Please Buy Your Ticket ($15) at: http://tinyurl.com/qe8f69r
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet in Zankel Hall at  TEACHERS COLLEGE, 525 West 120th St. (#1 to W 116, or M4, M5, M11, M60, or M104 to W 120 St.)
results.name: 2 Part Workshop: "Whiteboarding as a Verb" and "Expanding Your Resource Bank"

results.description: service at North Church Queens starts at 10 am and goes till 11 am. then there is fellowship which i like to call snacks and a low key party. the gardens are beautiful to visit. the bible is read by someone in the congregation. passages are the same for many of the churches regardless of the denomination- some set calendar thing that many Christian Churches go by. we sing some songs which is fun cause our organist really rocks! then there is the sermon which are most often, very interesting. we say some prayers, get forgiven for our sins~ as we forgive others who sin against us. communion is every first sunday. it is bread and grape juice in those individual small plastic shot glass type things.
results.name: Go to Church!

group.name: Spirituality, Exercise & Peace @ North Church Queens

results.description:
Hike a nice 7.5 mile loop in Harriman around Island Pond, including the climb up through the Lemon Squeezer on the Appalachian Trail and a chance to check out the old Boston Mine!  A fun, picturesque adventure. This should take us about 4 to 5 hours. 

Please  bring Harriman map 119 along with you.

We meet at 10:15am for a prompt 10:30am start.

<a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-g540MUecu9s/ViMVeN8XcSI/AAAAAAAB0Bw/mEhrLTZ8V8s/s1600/island-pond-mnt-lemon-squeezer-01.jpg"></a>

Island Pond

Lemon Squeezer



Trailhead GPS coordinates:[masked],[masked]

Driving Directions

Take N.Y. Route 17 north through Sloatsburg, Tuxedo and Southfields. About two miles north of Southfields, turn right onto Arden Valley Road. Cross the bridge over the New York State Thruway, then make the first right at a sign "Hikers' Trailhead Parking." Park in the dirt parking area to the west of a large meadow, known as the Elk Pen.

Sara cell[masked] No calls or texts until 24hrs before hike please

++

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back. See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.
results.name: Harriman- Island Pond and Lemon Squeezer

results.description:
Uncover the power of a quieter mind and ensure the renewal of a healthier you through movement, breath, and meditation. I welcome each student to come escape the bustle of the city to experience above and find their inner guru in my  class!

WELCOME TO FALL YOGA! 

As Summer officially draws to an end, we look forward to a process of  reaping the harvest and letting go.  Fall is a time of transition and it is evident everywhere around us.  After the glorious celebration of summer, the trees and shrubs are undressing in preparation for the winter, the air is crisping, and the wind is whispering coming of the winter tides.  Although this may leave us feeling slightly down, the possibility to strip down to a quiet essence of being and and savor the simplicity is an opportunity for introspection.  Come slow and quiet down with us in a practice to balance the Vata dosha and learn how you can best take care of yourself this season....  


Since March 2013, this donation based Meet Up group has aimed to provide a light-hearted and non-competitive space.  One can expect clear instructions, demonstration, gentle hands-on assistance, and achieve greater flexibility, strength, balance, focus, and sense of ease with regular attendance.  

Extra mats and blocks are limited, kindly bring yours if you have them.


*To offset Meetup Organizer's fees, a suggested donation between $7-10 will be greatly appreciated*

Thank you and please do post any questions.  I hope to see you soon! 

Jennifer ( 500 Hour Yoga Alliance Registered  Teacher)
results.name: FALL YOGA NOW INDOORS

group.name: GRAND ARMY PLAZA  YOGA MEETUP AND YIN YANG YOGA FO

results.name: Eat at Panera

results.description:
Platform presentation by Peter Gross, Executive Director since 2014 of the Clearwater, an environmental awareness and education organization centered on the Hudson River valley.

What creates the individual bonds needed for fostering real, life-long commitment to the environment? The powerful connections are not easily created in classrooms or by books. Much of the answer lies in our providing opportunities to experience nature. But even if we do that successfully, we ask, whom are we reaching and who responds to calls for action to protect the environment? Sadly, the people who are concerned and willing to act come mostly from a small segment of society. If we are going to make significant progress, we must change the paradigms by finding ways to broaden the base of voices demanding that change.


Light refreshments after the program.

Regular Ethical Education for Children classes today.
results.name: Engaging People in Environmental Action: A Clearwater Perspective

results.description:
Healing The World One Inner Child At A Time With Dr. Jay Kantor

Each of us has an Inner Child, an aspect of our mind created in childhood that lasts a lifetime. If we were hurt in childhood, our Inner Child lives with that trauma until we heal it, no matter how long it takes. Healing and nurturing a wounded Inner Child – learning what it really means to love ourselves unconditionally – is the critical step in a person’s spiritual development we will explore today.

Dr. Jay Kantor, who holds a Ph.D. in Psychology from Columbia University, began utilizing the Inner Child concept in 1990 to help people overcome the effects of inadequate parenting and parental abuse. Jay combines the use of Inner Child Psychology with other forms of energy and spiritual healing to help people overcome long-term emotional, psychological, and relationship problems, which have not responded to talk or drug therapies.
results.name: Healing The World One Inner Child At A Time With Dr. Jay Kantor

results.description:
By popular demand, let's get some pre-thanksgiving turkish at the Turkish Kitchen (the bird was named after the country).

This upscale Sunday brunch buffet is a veritable new york institution, and features traditional brunch fare with a turkish twist, including classic mezes, kebabs and more.

The cost will be $22 plus tax and tip. Please bring cash only, No Exceptions. Drinks will be paid for separately.

Turkish Kitchen is well reviewed on Yelp. Excerpts include:

"Not knowing much about Turkish cuisine, we figured we should first experiment with the Sunday brunch (currently priced at $21.95/person) where we could try a bit of everything...and what do you know, we absolutely loved the food!

BRUNCH: The entire meal was gratifying. There were three tables of pastries, fresh vegetables, mixed salads, humus/yogurt dips, dolmas, olives, seafood, beef, chicken, fruits, desserts (see pic)...and we had a bite of almost every item! Everything was tasty, had fresh ingredients and was bursting with all kinds of spices and herbs...and of course, lots of olive oil! Some of the flavors were a little strong for my palate, but regardless, I was impressed with the diversity. The desserts (rice pudding, fruit cocktail, flan, baklava, etc) were amazing...all sinfully rich and sweet.

AMBIANCE: Very cool...with RED everywhere. There's a large bar on the first floor; therefore, naturally, the second floor dining room is quieter and more reserved.

SERVICE: Everyone was generally polite. (We might've have the same server that Deborah H. had, because he was awfully playful!)

SUM: Thanks, Turkish Kitchen, for a wonderful introduction to Turkish cuisine."

"Wow, where do I start...When a Turkish friend whose judgement you trust invites you to brunch over the bridge in Manhattan, you go. Because Turkish food rocks when it is made right and this is the guy who introduced me to Taci's in Brooklyn, I had high expectations.

As good as I hoped the buffet would be, it was even better,  In fact there were so many delicious choices, it was hard to narrow down what to put on my plate during each visit back to the buffet! Round one: Turkish bread and croissants, smoked salmon, cheeses, salads, olives, yogurt, mashed eggplant, humous,  homemade stuffed grape leaves, cheese borek, orange juice, coffee....Round two, ground lamb, lamb gyro, chicken shish kebab and more humous. There was also talapia for the fish eaters and rice which I opted not to fill up on. And then came round three. I tried to be good, I really did. I took some fruit and mellon but the baklava and five or six other Turkish pastries looked so lonely, so I knew in my heart that I just had to find them a home in my stomach!  And of course more coffee...but you can also get tea.

Everything was well prepared and spiced. Likewise the staff was friendly, professional and helpful. And Louise, the bathrooms were nicely tiled!

My only suggestions are that they find a way to serve the Turkish bread warm...difficult but not impossible with a buffet. Be careful to not overcook the chicken (mine was a tad dry) and please don't dump the extra ice in the urnal because it takes it out of commission!

At $21.95, this Sunday brunch is worth the price!"
results.name: Sunday Brunch at Turkish Kitchen

Dr. Anne Klaeysen, Leader presides 

Every nation, including the United States, has adopted the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to guide global cooperation until 2030.  Americans still know little about these new global goals.  Yet the SDGs could be a powerful moral and political approach for the US to reinvigorate the American Dream.  They can help our country to address and overcome our massive interconnected crises of inequality, unemployment, environmental degradation, and declining trust 

Jeffrey D. Sachs is the Director of the Earth Institute at Columbia University, Special Advisor to UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, Director of the UN Sustainable Development Solutions Network, and Winner of the 2015 Blue Planet Prize.

results.description:
Since we love Hiking, so why not Hike to w a True Adventure a REAL Ghost Town" "Doodle-town" What makes the this hike so interesting is the history of the area.

The name is said to derive from the Dutch Dooddel, or "dead valley", with the "town" suffix added later by English-speaking settlers.


Doodletown was an isolated hamlet in the Town of Stony Point, Rockland County, New York, United States. Purchased by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission during the 1960s, it is now part of Bear Mountain State Park and a popular destination for hikers, birdwatchers, botanists, and local historians. It is located north of Jones Point, west of Iona Island, and southeast of Orange County. The former settlement is now a ghost town.

The settlement was a crossroads for soldiers during the Revolutionary War during battles at Bear Mountain's Fort Montgomery when many hundreds of British soldiers marched through the tiny settlement prior to a bloody and significant battle with colonists. The Doodletown Road was used by troops accompanying Mad Anthony Wayne on his successful attack on Stony Point.[


Early residents worked as loggers and miners, and the remains of the mines are still visible today. There were also small farms and businesses. Others worked at the Iona Island Picnic Grove, a resort built on Iona Island after the Civil War. Around 1900 the United States Navy purchased Iona for an ammunition depot. In 1903 there was a severe explosion at the site, and a worker

In the 1890s, Thomas Edison bought a defunct iron mine in Doodletown to test his proposed technique for an improved method of refining ore. Nothing came of his project, although several iron mines had been successfully developed and abandoned in the neighborhood at a much earlier date.from Doodletown was killed.


By the 1920s, the height of population for Doodletown, the settlement had a school, a church, several small businesses, two cemeteries and approximately 70 homes. At least several families had lived there for generations. Around this era, military and tourism-related enterprises on nearby Iona Island employed residents, as did the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.


Members of the first family to settle in Doodletown during the 18th century, French Huguenots whose name was anglicanized to "June," were also the very last to leave it in the 1960s.

Other residences were maintained as second homes or were inhabited by retired people from the New York City area, and Doodletown's population thus reached its historic peak of about 350 residents


The Demise



In its peak in the 1920's, Doodletown had a new, larger school, the finest building in the town. There were three primary roads, a lane connecting to Seven Lakes Drive, several dead end lanes, two working cemeteries, and approximately seventy homes. Many families like the Junes, Herberts and Weyants had lived there for generations.

BUT, Beginning ca 1921, and throughout the following decades, the Park began to expand its borders by slowly purchasing the settlements properties. Many of these properties were then rented out to Park employees. In 1962, the Park planned to build a ski resort where Doodletown was located. The residents were to be bought out. Some were relieved to be able to sell. At the time, homeowners were unable to secure home improvement loans, and buyers were unable to obtain mortgages, since the lenders felt that the town's demise was inevitable. Others, strongly resisted, and were threatened with condemnation through eminent domain. In early 1965, the last of the Doodletown residents had moved out. This included the June family, whose members had lived there continuously since 1762. Ironically, the ski resort was never built. The Park now owned all of the land, except for the two cemeteries. In 1966, the buildings were demolished and the debris was buried. The town was left to revert to its natural state, wild and largely overgrown.

The last remaining building, the stone school house, was kept as a shelter for hikers until vandalism caused the park commission to tear it down in 1980.


Today, many foundations, walls, and staircases are still visible. The area is accessible by various trails and former roadways. The town's cemeteries contain graves ranging from centuries old to much more recent years, as former residents and their relatives can still choose to be buried there. Steel signage has recently been installed by the park service, listing which families owned each property and often showing photographs of former buildings. Orientation signs are located at intervals throughout the area.


We will See the, sidewalks, cellar holes, wells, walls and foundations, with photos to show how they once appeared when lived in. Visit three cemeteries, including one that is "lost". Plus, explore its secret places such as the ancient Indian rock shelter, the Tree Nursery, Doodletown Mine, Edison Mine, the town's swimming hole, and secluded waterfalls. The tour rambles past a beautiful small reservoir, along old roads and paths, past pretty streams through beautiful woods, valleys and hills, with magnificent mountain views

35 min Ride each way-

results.description: The Sunday School at the Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County helps children aged 2-14 explore and develop their moral and critical thinking skills through fun and interactive lessons and field trips. We meet weekly at 11am on Sundays for 1.5 hours while the adults of the Ethical Culture Society are attending the platform meeting. Our wide ranging curriculum allows kids to examine themselves, their community and the world in general. We teach about different cultures, philosophies and religions. We encourage our students to ask questions, think for themselves and make up their own minds about the bigger questions in life. Our children develop strong values and ethical standpoints. The Sunday School Graduation Rite of Passage, completed by our 8th graders, allows them to present to the community how their Sunday School experience has informed their moral and ethical development.

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
Speaker: Curt Collier, FormerLeader

Details: The recent fight over the push to ban the incandescent light bulb is indicative of what is wrong with American views on environmentalism.  Despite the overwhelming evidence that we need to ban these diminutive energy hogs many Americans cling to the bulb as yet another misguided symbol of the struggle against a supposedly overbearing government.  What is really at the heart of this imprudent behavior, and how can reframing this debate impact other needed changes as well?</a>

About the Speaker: Curt Collier is a former Leader of the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture. He is now Deputy Director of Groundwork Hudson Valley and a Leader at the New York Society for Ethical Culture.

For more information:http://www.rysec.org/event/change-light-bulb <a href="http://www.rysec.org/event/community-for-freethinkers">


Sunday programs are held at 11:00 AM at the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture. For more information, please visit our website: <a>http://www.rysec.org </a>;
results.how_to_find_us: Directions on website or call the office during the week.
results.name: How Many Americans Does it Take to Change a Lightbulb?

results.description:
Join us for a 4-5 mile Hike with Intermediate Rock Scrambles at Giant Stairs (Palisades Interstate Park)

This hike explores the northern end of the New Jersey Section of the Palisades Interstate Park. It is, perhaps, the most rewarding loop hike in the park, as it incorporates a number of scenic features and, for nearly the entire distance, you are far away from the noise of the Parkway. But it is also the most difficult hike in the park, as it involves not only steep climbs and descents on uneven rock steps, but also nearly a mile of walking near the shore of the river on jumbled rocks.

As a special treat we will be making a small detour off the beginning of our loop  to see the Woman's Federation Monument Castle!

Unlike previous visits you may have made to Giants Stairs, we will be focusing on further exploration of some of the boulders and crevices along the shoreline. If you choose not to join us on the shoreline scramble, please be prepared to lead yourself for the duration of the hike along the established trail.

Please Note that these scrambles will be more advanced than the traditional trail!

We will meet at: The Parking area by the State Line Cafe by the State Line Lookout

Driving Directions:

Take the Palisades Interstate Park north from the George Washington Bridge. Continue for 1.7 miles beyond Exit 2, and turn right at a sign for the State Line Lookout. Follow the access road for about half a mile until it ends at a large parking lot near the lookout. (If you are coming from the north on the Parkway, bear left just beyond Exit 3 and follow the signs for the lookout).

Distance:  Approximately 4-5 miles

Hiking Pace:  Slow but physically challenging

Estimated Hike Time:  3-4 hours

Difficulty:  Intermediate (or Fit Beginners with a good sense of balance and no abnormal fear of heights) - Rocky Terrain, Scrambling, steep Ascents and Descents with a total of approx 700' elevation gain

Current Weather Forecast:  Sunny with a high of 54 degrees

RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Gloves - Lightweight with good grip - Gardening gloves from Home Depot work great!

• Shoes with good grip - preferably with ankle support

• A Small Pack - nothing too large that will become a hindrance in the scrambles

• Related maps, a compass or GPS, Water, Snacks, First Aid, etc.

Related Maps:

New York - New Jersey Trail Conference - Hudson Palisades Trails Map

(Specifically Trail Map 109)

AFTER THE EVENT FEEL FREE TO JOIN US FOR FOOD AND DRINKS AT THE FILLING STATION!

243 Route 9W, Palisades, NY 10964

Mon - Sun: 6:30 am - 9:00 pm

Parking Lot Available

[masked]

http://the9wfillingstation.com/



**HEAVY RAIN WILL CANCEL THIS EVENT**

results.description:
Folks, 
Inviting volunteers to join me at the St Xaviers Church Soup Kitchen on Sunday to serve over 1000 meals to the poor and homeless provided by St Xaviers Pantry.

This is based on the values that we would treat everyone equal,trustworthy, with dignity without any discrimination. We also want to be socially inclusive, including everyone with their preferences, culture and celebrate diversity. We will serve vegetarian dishes. The Soup Kitchen is dependent on volunteers to help work towards sustaining these values our community. If you are interested in being a volunteer, rsvp through this page. You don't have to be particularly skillful, we believe that if you have the passion, that's all that's needed :)


Soup Kitchen provides the aprons, gloves, hairnets. (one can wear their own baseball hat). Long hair need to be tied back unless it all fit in the hair net. We work with you, show you what to do. Please wear something comfortable.

Type of help could vary from coordinating the line, serving meals, Removing empty plates from the table or general helping out. 

Location -

 Church of St. Francis Xavier (Basement Hall)

46 W. 16th Street (Between 6th and 5th Avenue), New York, NY

Time -

11:30 - 3:30 ( You are required to stay till the end)

I will put my number on the meetup wall once we get close to the date. Members might get different responsibilities but will try to work as a group.
results.name: Vounteer At St Xavier's Church Soup Kitchen - Feed the Homeless, Good Karma!

Educational seminar and Q&A. 

Light brunch refreshments will be served.

Presentation begins promptly at 11:30am.

Bring your PSEG bill with you to design your home solar system and see how much money you could save with the different lease, finance, and purchase options that are available.

Topics covered: Solar growth on Long Island, NYSERDA rebates, NYS tax credits, Federal Tax Credits, Property Tax abatement, NYS On-bill financing program, the SunPower lease, case studies.

results.description:
Hi ladies, 

The Church of St Francis Xavier does weekly soup kitchen and clothing drives. Let's support their efforts by spending a few hours on Sun Aug 16th feeding the hungry!

Food will need to be served to patrons and the kitchen cleared post service. In the past over 1,000 meals have been served to the poor.

Please RSVP as soon as possible and if you would like to attend but can't stay the whole 4hrs contact me prior to entering your RSVP.

This community outreach is dependent on us volunteers so your commitment to spending your time is generous and appreciated! Can't wait to see you all there!

Contact me with any questions.

Note: a wait list has been activated as the number of volteers is limited; wear comfortable clothes and shoes

I will be in attendance for the 8:30am food prep service and not this event that starts at 11:30am but hope to greet you upon arrival.

http://stfrancispantries.org/community-programs/sunday-meals-at-st-francis-xavier-soup-kitchen.html

Regards,

Janell

We gather in the saloon’s back room, where we have enough privacy to have different conversations around the several large tables, as well as the big one led by Dorothy Kahn.

The expanded pub-grub menu has been enhanced with an $11 breakfast special, the Bloody Marys are hot, the beer is cold, and conversation sparkles.

Come join 20 or more freethinkers for food, fun and conversation.

Discussion: 

The Trump Phenomenon: Wherefore and Why?
results.name: SHSNY Brunch & Conversation

results.description:
Hello y'all! For this weekend's meetup we'll be talking about - what else! - the upcoming presidential primaries. By now everyone has had at least one debate, there are still a zillion Republican candidates, and Hillary seems to be shoring up support. I'm sure thoughts 

Our second topic will be the recent downed Russian plane over the Sinai peninsula. Accident? Terrorism? The jury is out - but the response by Russian and international teams is illustrative of the tense political situation that surrounds Russian involvement in Syria and relations in general.

We'll finish with Friday's announcement of President Obama's rejection of the Keystone Pipeline proposal. It's been a long fought battle ultimately won by environmentalists, but it's also largely symbolic. What, if anything, does it mean for the battle over global warming?
results.name: Elections, Russian Plane Crash, & the End of Keystone

Play in Central Park on grass... real grass! 10v10, 60min+


Arrive early to warm up, and be ready to start at 11:00am. ALL players need to bring a white and black t-shirt.


It's a 10min walk from 96th street subway. Map below...

************************************************************

DETAILS:

The match is played on grass, so cleats are strongly recommended.


1) Teams divide into equal ability, so sides are even.


2) Players are welcome to sign-up with friends.


3) Rough play and slide tackles are not tolerated.

4) Goals are large size 8'x18.

5) If you arrive late, please wait to be asked to join the game. Inserting players in the middle of the game can disrupt the flow.


All players must RSVP and make payment before game time, this goes toward the field permits, equipment, fees and any light rentals.


CANCELLATIONS/REFUNDS:

If you won't be able to make the game, you need to change your RSVP to "not going" 24 hours before the match to receive a credit for the next game. This is so other members have a chance to take your place. If a session is postponed or moved you will receive a full refund.

results.description: On an ordinary day, the Alexandria Ceremonial Police Orchestra arrives in Israel from Egypt for a cultural event, only find there is no delegation to meet them, nor any arrangements to get to their destination of Petah Tiqva. When they find their own ride, they arrive instead at the remote town of Beit Hatikva. Stuck there until the next morning's bus, the band, lead by the repressed Tawfiq Zacharaya, gets help from the worldly lunch owner, Dina, who offers to put them up for the night. As the band settles in as best it can, each of the members attempts to get along with the natives in their own way. What follows is a special night of quiet happenings and confessions as the band makes its own impact on the town and the town on them.

results.description:
Advancing Atheism into a Post-Dawkins Era  /SUNDAY / NOVEMBER  8TH / NYC ATHEISTS BRUNCH / TYSON GILL / 12NOON

--------------------------------------------------------------


SPEAKER: TYSON GILL

TOPIC: Advancing Atheism into a Post-Dawkins Era


Tyson is the author of “Belief in Science and the Science of Belief: A Guidebook to Fact-Based Thinking” (found here). He is also an NYCA Member and frequent contributor to our NYCA Newsletter.

This month Tyson will challenge our thinking about atheism and the atheist movement. He makes a compelling case that while the Four Horsemen have been the vanguard of our movement, we now risk premature détente with religion. In order to achieve the enduring and substantive changes that our society so desperately needs, we can and must advance our attitudes and tactics to enter into what he calls the Post-Dawkins era of the movement.

LOCATION: The Press Box Restaurant (2nd Floor) 932 Second Avenue Street (bet. 49th & 50th Sts.).

COST: BRUNCH, $20, includes selection of buffet entrees, salad, one soft drink, coffee, tax and tip.

===================================
results.how_to_find_us: 2ND FLOOR
results.name: Advancing Atheism into a Post-Dawkins Era /SUN. NOV. 8 /NYCA BRUNCH / TYSON GILL

results.description: More turmoil in the Mediterranean. We'll conclude the major period of Carthaginian - Roman clashes that began in the 3rd century BC with a discussion of the third Punic War, which followed Rome's heeding the call,"Carthago delenda est". We'll backtrack a bit to cover the Macedonian and Seleucid Wars, which were going on concurrently with the Second and Third Punic Wars. And finally, we'll transition into the period leading up to the next discussion by looking at early 2nd century Rome including the impact of the Scipionic circle.
results.name: Beware the Punic Curse!

results.description:
COME &  join us for a fun afternoon to paint this painting, no art experience needed.  This will be a copy of Henri Matisse's "Flowers on Chair"  You will take home your own painting ready to be framed. A guided painting class.

In a relaxed, social setting, an experienced artist will guide the class step-by-step through replicating the days featured painting. It's easy, fun, and totally stress free. Many people find our classes therapeutic and convenient way to tap back into their creative side, and go home with a painting you can be proud of.

The class is $29.00 for 2 hours

 These classes are designed for beginners, yet there is plenty to challenge students of all skill levels. The first step is to trace the image using a stencil, this way we can start painting right away. Then our instructors will cover basic techniques and guide you step-by-step through every aspect of the painting. At Painting Lounge, we pride ourselves on our hands on teaching approach. Instructors will walk around the class to answer questions and to make sure everyone is on the right track. It's good to remember that with art there are no “right” or “wrong” answers.

$29 for one Guided Painting Workshop ($50 value)

Two hours of expert painting instruction 

All supplies necessary, including the canvas, paint, brushes, aprons, and easel.

Take home your very own 16x20" original showpiece at the end of the nightply reinterpreted as intentional strokes of genius.

To register for the class, first RSVP here for our Meet UP, then use this Rush coupon so the class will be $29.00 (not the normal class fee of $50.00).  Then follow the prompts on Rush to register for the class.

Here is the link to Rush http://rush49.com/deals/painting-lounge?gclid=CjwKEAjwwbyxBRCS74T049iEp0wSJACkO5v1aZ3mIcS259ix_9pHvEUrFkHjP2BHTHqdrE8-JCHtNxoCKaXw_wcB

#4063 at 12:30 PMHenri    Matisse, "Flowers on Chair"

(2hr, Midtown, Front Room)</a> <a href="https://www.rezclick.com/paintinglounge/images/Class-large/Image-4063.jpg">enlarge image 19 openings available

THE PAINTING WE ARE DOING FOR THIS CLASS IS THE 1ST PAINTING YOU SEE ABOVE, IT IS HENRI MATISSE "FLOWERS ON CHAIR"

I ALSO POSTED IT AGAIN BELOW THIS DESCRIPTION

Henri Matisse
"Flowers on Chair"
2-hour Class

A bursting bouquet of flowers that is sure to brighten any room. This painting works well with  alternate colors in case you want to get extra creative!

About Henri Matisse:
Matisse is considered the most important French artist of the 20th century and, along with Pablo Picasso, one of the most influential modernist painters of the last century.

A student of the masters of Post-Impressionism, Matisse later made a reputation for himself as the leader of a group of painters known as Les Fauves. An ironic label given to them by a critic (it means "wild beasts"), the name reflected Matisse's aggressive strokes and bold use of primary colors.

I'M LOOKING FORWARD TO THIS CLASS IT WILL BE A LOT OF FUN.

ALSO, IF YOU WANT TO BRING WINE TO DRINK, THEY PROVIDE CUPS AND ICE.

Many have expressed interest in, or have recently started development on their web-series. Coming in early November, the Producer's Panel Presents: How to Make a Web Series. 

In this panel discussion members who are also web-series producers will walk you through how they made their series come alive. From script development, to casting, to location scouting, to production budgets, connect with other members who have done it, and done it well.


Moderated by our own fabulous Daralyn Jay, we're fortunate to be joined by the following panelists:

Brittney Coleman, the writer, producer and lead actress of Coming Home, now shooting it's 2nd season.


Roger Omeus, the writer, director and producer of Finding Me, now shooting it's 3rd season.

Mercedes Brazier, the writer and creator of All My Friends are Married, soon to release it's first season. 

Huriyyah Muhammad, the producer of All My Friends are Married, soon to release it's first season.


Also, take advantage of a web-series producer's packet that will be distributed to help you along the way. 

Looking forward to seeing you all there!

results.description:
A small, supportive group for artists of all types to come together and talk about and share their creative projects in a fun, non-judgmental environment. New members welcome. (Each person pays $1 cash at the meetings, just to help offset the costs of having the group hosted here on MeetUp.com.)

Every week, we meet from 12:00 pm to 2:00 pm. Usually, we work through Julia Cameron's creativity building techniques (for example those in The Artist's Way and The Prosperous Heart). We start each session discussing the current week's activity (morning pages, artist's dates, synchronicities, creative endeavors, etc) and then participate in an agreed upon exercise/task (bring paper and pen please).


Normally, on the third Sunday of the month, we share our artistic projects in a kind of "Show & Tell" so that we can get to know each other's work and support it. Not mandatory - only for those who wish to share or present their work.


This is a very creative and supportive small group. Please join us.

results.description:
Updated October 8th, 2015

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

FALL (Sep - Nov)

As the city cools down we play four times a week. We use Riverside Park on weekdays and Morningside Park for weekends.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Morningside Park (110th & Manhattan Ave) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Morningside Park (110th & Manhattan Ave) 
- Tuesdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End) 
- Thursdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)

Damien 
[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

results.description:
RSVP's Closed

PLEASE READ THIS CAREFULLY BEFORE YOU RSVP. I TAKE THE RSVP PROCESS SERIOUSLY AND EXPECT THAT YOU SHOULD TOO.

Join me and AMC club members who do not have to RSVP on a fast paced 5-6 mile hiking tour concentrating on the North End of Central Park. I was not planning to do anything in Central Park until my annual New Year’s Day Hike but the Fall Foliage in Prospect Park last week changed my plans.

This will be more hike than tour though we will stop a number of times to talk very briefly about what we see. You’ll see waterfalls, woods,which we will walk into, old forts-sort of, the Conservatory Gardens and there will always be additional surprises. WE WILL FINISH AROUND 5 P.M. NO FOOD STOPS.

We leave ON TIME. BE READY TO GO. I WILL SEND AN E-MAIL WITH MEETING DETAILS  SATURDAY EVENING.

Please consider joining the Appalachian Mountain Club (AMC) ) http://www.amc-ny.org/ The Club offers many hikes, walks and events and is also active in conservation efforts and trail maintenance. Only a few of the many hikes and walks that are offered by AMC leaders are posted on Meetup. 

Since this event will be posted as a last minute hike to AMC Club members there is NO need for AMC Club members to RSVP for this-UNLESS you do not get last minute e-mails about Club events-and you should in order to fully take advantage of your membership. IF YOU ARE A DUES PAYING AMC MEMBER AND DON’T GET THESE E-MAILS, LET ME KNOW A FEW DAYS BEFORE THE EVENT AND I’LL TELL YOU HOW. Let’s leave 10 spaces for AMC Meetup members. Priority will be given to those who have previously attended other AMC Meetup events-it does not have to be mine-and have some attachment to the Club.

Needless to say, please take the RSVP process seriously and be considerate to me and your fellow Meetup members. If you’ve been a NO SHOW  on any AMC Meetup event that I have led –see your attendance history-or you are a chronic abuser of the RSVP process, please do not RSVP. Unfortunately, you will not be able to attend.

I am going to ask that people not post any comments or questions prior to the event. You will have all the information you need to do this once you get the meeting place details. No offense, but I don’t need to know what you are doing that day (and probably neither does anyone else) if you can’t make it or what you think the weather will be. AFTER the event, post as many comments and photos as you like.

If the weather is really bad or there is a really bad forecast, Check Accuweather like I do, I will post a notice by very early on the day of the event cancelling. If there is no notice, we go.

First Timers, READ details before you RSVP. 

Where: The Cliffs at LIC, [masked]th Drive, Long Island City, NY

When: We usually climb between 1:00pm and 4:00 pm. There is no strict start time and the organizer(s) tries their best to be there around 1:00pm. We will pair off around 1.15ish and start climbing. 

Transportation: Subway: E, M trains to 23rd St-Ely Ave (1/2 block from gym) 7, G train to Court Square (2 blocks from gym)* N, Q train to Queens Borough Plaza (10min walk) *Walk to the E & M track for those bad weather days 

Metro North & LIRR: From Grand Central take 7 train 3 stops From Penn Station take Uptown E train to Court Square

Cost/Discount: Monthly membership of $105 (the $99 Initiation Fee is waived if you sign up during the meet up). Just mention "Rock & Ice" at the front desk in order to receive your discount. Gear rental is free for first-timers ONLY  (first time visit to the facility). Regular gear  pricing info can be found here: http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/climbing/pricing/
For Beginners, Climbing 101 class is offered 50% Off if you do it the same day as the meet up and has to be scheduled in advance with them.</a>

How to meet us:  After you checked-in, to the right of the front desk there's a sitting area.If you see a group of people in there that's probably us come and say hi. If you are running late or can't find the group leave a message in the Comments section.  Food/drinks apres-climb at John Brown Smokehouse next door (or whichever resto the group decides). Even if you only want to have a beer with us, that is also acceptable :)

Notice to Beginners: If you have never climbed before, we encourage you to take the Climbing 101 class there before attending the meetup. We get a discounted price of $25 for the class (that's 50% Off original price if you do it the same day as the meet up and has to be scheduled in advance with them). This will also cover your day pass + gear for the day. Unfortunately we can't teach you how to belay or let you try to belay at the gym if you are not belay certified yet. We leave the teaching to the experts.  Check out Cliff's website for more details.  What to wear - comfortable clothes (think yoga).

Notice to newcomers: You need to pass a belay certification. If you had belayed before, the test takes couple of minutes. If you need a refresher, a test partner or belay partner, please see feel free to see me. Here is the link to The Cliffs LIC <a href="http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/">http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/

If you decide to stick with the sport, please peruse our message boards for good deals on climbing shoes and other gear.  Also if you find this group invaluable, please donate and pay your voluntary membership due ;) the Organizers will love you more ;)
results.name: Weekend Climbing at the Cliffs LIC

results.description:
Transmission Meditation with Meryl Tihanyi Alternate Sundays Beginning March 1st
1:00-3:00pm
Free Do you want to help the world and also build a stronger connection with your own spiritual nature? Transmission Meditation is a simple group meditation that provides both a dynamic service to the world and the opportunity for powerful personal spiritual development. *It is a group meditation based on the Science of Triangles, that makes possible the scientific distribution or transmission of highly potent spiritual energies into the world.
*It is the creation, in conscious co-operation with the Masters of Wisdom, of a vortex or pool of higher energy for the benefit of humanity.
*It is a combination of two yogas: Karma yoga (the yoga of service) and Laya yoga (the yoga of energy or chakras).
*Introduced to the world in 1974 by artist and author Benjamin Creme, there are now hundreds of Transmission Meditation groups active in many countries around the world.
*It is safe, and will enhance and complement any other spiritual practice or service activity in which you may already be engaged. Come to a FREE introduction to Transmission Meditation, followed by a group meditation.
results.name: Transmission Meditation with Meryl Tihanyi

results.description:
It's back, by popular demand!!

A glass of wine, a loaf of bread...and thy Pug! What could be better than a road trip up to dog-friendly Warwick Valley Winery?!?

This meetup will be weather-dependent, of course (but we are banking on yet another nice Autumn weekend before we need to go into our "Winter Hibernation" mode...:). The winery has a nice, outdoor sitting area to accommodate dogs and their owners, along with an outdoor wine-tasting area. They also have a wonderful selection of food available inside within their cafe. The optional wine tasting is $5.00, and that includes sampling 6 different wines and a glass. It's roughly a 40-50 minute drive from the Northern NJ area (which would prove to be quite beautiful this time of year, with the leaves creating a palette of orange, brown and yellow hues to beckon us onwards...  :)

Here's a link to the winery website for additional details: http://wvwinery.com/

If you are interested in this meetup and are available for the scheduled date, please RSVP as soon as possible so I can have some idea of how many people would be attending.

Cheers and see you soon!

Ellen
results.name: It's a Warwick Valley Winery Road Trip!

results.description:
Dear Dharma Friends,

We will be holding a moving and sitting meditation followed by a Dharma talk on the 6-Paramitas, part 3.

1:00 - 2:00 Sitting/moving meditation 

2:00 - 3:00 Lecture 

The lecture will be given by teacher Harry Miller.  Harry  studied  with  Master  Sheng  Yen  for  over  30  years.  He  was  editor  of  the  Chan  Newsletter  for  over  10  years,  is  a  frequent  contributor  to  Chan  Magazine,  and  a  lecturer  at  Chan  Meditation  Center (CMC).  He  is  a  board  member  of  Dharma  Drum  Retreat  Center  and  a  member  of  the  Dharma  Teachers  in  Training  at  CMC.  He  holds  a  B.A  in  French  and  English  literature  from  Sarah  Lawrence,  and  an  M.A.  in  Chinese  Literature  and  M.Phil.  in  Comparative  Literature  from  Columbia  University.

Look forward to seeing everyone,

_/|\_

Organizer

------------------------------------------------------

Dharma Drum Mountain Buddhist Association is an orthodox Zen/Chan international organization.  Their New York area affiliates info are the following links: <<a>www. chancenter.org</a>> <www.dharmadrumretreat.org>
